148227797.review:
Harebrained's Cyberpunk Returns was a pretty major return for classic RPGs back when the genre was still in decline but also Kickstarter looked fresh, new and reliable so many projects got funded - and this was one of those that delivered. But looking back in a time when subgenre stands firm again, while followups aged like finest of wines, original Returns really meanders.

Basic lowdown - in game's setting, starting 1980s some divergences led to way more corporate future, and in 2012 magic awakened as per Mayan calendar, leading to elf and dwarf kids being born to regular humans, and spellcasting being quickly rediscovered as a potent and useful force on par with engineering and medicine. Going trough ecological catastrophes, wars, state dissolutions and corporate conflict world steadily turns into eclectic and unusual mix of trite on their own cyberpunk and fantasy concepts. There's megacorps run by instinctively greedy dragons, street samurais are either cyborgs or chi-channeling martial artists, and evil spirits are as credible of a threat as street gangs. The gameplay meanwhile, is a mix of tactical ability and weapon attack-focused turn based combat and dialogue conversations, with skills unlocking new dialogue choices and interactions outside combat, plus new cool combat moves. There's some neat ideas borrowed from original tabletop rpg, like charisma allowing you to learn how to talk with particular groups like academicians, law enforcement, street folk or criminals, more easily getting their vibes and earning their trust, and your choices which to pick are freeform once you unlock a new one. The art style is really neat too, a mix of low-poly 3D and painterly isometric art.

Now where this doesn't age well is both the story, which while nice and a good introduction to setting just fails to bloom into something truly memorable, and then general gameplay variety just lacking comparing to what came later on with Dragonfall and Hong Kong. Balance or lack of variety for some freeform "classes" really can make gameplay feel like a slog at certain points, balance isn't as smooth so certain parts are too easy and others too tough, and in general the drive to push the plot isn't as strong despite having the same approach to raising the stakes from dealing with personal problems to saving the world or a multi-million popular metropolis as followups. While the followup expandalones I couldn't put down, this one I abandoned without completing - and that was before the CRPG revival got into high gear!

It goes cheap on the sales, but if you take the full trilogy and find this one uninteresting just move on to Dragonfall instead of assuming the entire series is same level of meh. I can see you fully enjoying this one too though - but if so oh boy how you gonna love what comes next!

[h1] 𝕋𝕙𝕖 𝕗𝕚𝕣𝕤𝕥 𝕊𝕙𝕒𝕕𝕠𝕨𝕣𝕦𝕟 𝕘𝕒𝕞𝕖 𝕥𝕙𝕒𝕥 𝕔𝕒𝕡𝕥𝕚𝕧𝕒𝕥𝕖𝕕 𝕞𝕖 𝕓𝕒𝕔𝕜 𝕚𝕟 𝕥𝕙𝕖 𝕕𝕒𝕪, 𝕨𝕚𝕥𝕙 𝕚𝕥𝕤 ℂℝℙ𝔾 𝕒𝕞𝕒𝕫𝕚𝕟𝕖𝕤𝕤 𝕒𝕟𝕕 𝕚𝕥𝕤 𝕔𝕙𝕒𝕣𝕒𝕔𝕥𝕖𝕣𝕤 𝕥𝕙𝕒𝕥 𝕒𝕣𝕖 𝕆𝕤𝕔𝕒𝕣𝕤-𝕨𝕠𝕣𝕥𝕙𝕪, 𝕖𝕧𝕖𝕟 𝕥𝕙𝕠𝕦𝕘𝕙 𝕥𝕙𝕖𝕪 𝕟𝕖𝕧𝕖𝕣 𝕒𝕔𝕥𝕦𝕒𝕝𝕝𝕪 𝕦𝕥𝕥𝕖𝕣 𝕒 𝕤𝕚𝕟𝕘𝕝𝕖 𝕨𝕠𝕣𝕕. [/h1]

Shadowrun Returns is a remake of a famous very old Shadowrun game, more than that, Shadowrun includes other stories that you can play (by downloading them from the Mod Workshop), which means that you get great value from this simple-looking gem.

Shadowrun Returns is originally a CRPG, Tactical game where you play as... Yourself, a shadowrunner; individuals who take on jobs and heists that nets them a great deal of bank balance. After a job that went awry, one of your friends ends up dying! Upon answering a com in your appartement, you discover that the dead man has left you a voice mail, asking you to investigate his pending demise (the guy knew he was going to die, hence why the campaign is called The Dead Man's Switch). Quest after quest, you'll discover that the plot goes deeper than a simple shadow run gone wrong.

As in any other Shadowrun (or CRPG) game, you can be one of many classes; Decker, Shaman, Mage... Of course, being the promised prince that I am, I chose to go with Shaman, a mage that relies heavily on Charisma to be able to control outerworld demonic entities that you can summon from... trashcans lmfao! Welcome to Shadowrun, I guess. I've only played three classes in these games and they work great, you'll have no issues putting those Karma points into attributes you find would be useful. Visuals are average, very I might add, and here we pray that the devs could transcend Shadowrun finally to stand toe to toe against Next-Gen CRPGs like Pillars of Eternity.

Shadowrun Returns is a [b]7/10[/b], the only few things lacking are great visuals and an online multiplayer. Oh and did I mention that you could play as Cyberpunk Elves? That's right, Elves with visors and cybernetic augments... You should buy this game just for that!

145012576.review:
My first foray into Shadowrun world began with playing Returns on the Steam Deck. It ran very well. Played as a female Elf, proficient with decking and rifle.

It was mostly what I expected, although it did surprise me in a good way with the quality of written dialogues; text boxes before missions during a loading screen almost felt like something taken out of the paper RPG with very detailed descriptions of a predicament your main character is currently in and his/her surroundings - it really helped in making the world just a tad more believable.

The whole setting is what drawn me to Returns and I wasn't disappointed in that respect, although I would have liked the city and its regions to be a bit more open, with more optional stuff to do - so I could actually feel like I am the runner who's pulling the strings here, making my own choices, rather than being pulled by developers to finish the main quest only, by completing a sequence of linear missions and locations.

I've enjoyed the combat, it was balanced well, but not particularly deep or difficult; and very much enjoyed upgrading my character - there are no boundaries here after you pick your class and race which is fantastic (although a few limitations may occur). It is an approach that I wish more RPG games would implement, where you're not really limited by your chosen race/class, and you can still become whatever you want if you invest an x amount of points in y profession.

Story wise it was pretty good and fun to follow how the events unfolded in the main campaign - it's the ending that sort of spoiled it for me to be honest, it'd be interesting to see how probable would be this scenario within the realm of the original table top RPG - because here, it almost felt out of place and it really brought down the overall feeling of a pretty solid game for me... at one point I just couldn't believe what was going on, it was such a drastic shift in the narrative.

It is a solid experience, took me about 19hrs or so in total. However I would recommend it to others only with the above caveats taken into consideration. I also bought Dragonfall which I believe is the second entry in Harebrained Schemes' Shadowrun Trilogy & from what I've been hearing so far it improves on Returns in almost every possible way, so I am quite thrilled about playing it later this year.

Shadowrun Returns is one of the best turn-based RPGs going, particularly if you like cyberpunk.

142571063.review:
TL;DR - A 6/10 game.
But still a game I 100% recommend you play!
(I'll explain why, later on)


It's worth mentioning that I never played the original Shadowrun, tabletop or computer game.
And prior to this had no knowledge of the world of Shadowrun or it's lore.
So I'm looking at the game from a completely completely objective/fresh angle.


GRAPHICS
The game was a Kickstarter project, so it did not have huge budget to begin with. And it's also 10 years old already.
So there's not much to expect graphics wise.
The graphics are not terrible though. It's on par with many indie games release in 2023.
The one difference I found is that despite the view being isometric (which is common in RPG games), in this game you can only zoom in/out, but don't have an ability to change the camera angle (which has become the standard in modern game engines).
Also, there is almost no cutscenes and no voiceover. Everything is told via text.


CONTROLS
There are 2 very important concepts in Application development (any application, be it a game or a social network)
UI - meaning User Interface. How the screen looks like, how the buttons and menus look like. The graphics.
And UX - meaning User Experience. How the application behaves. What happens when you click a button. How easy it is to find the things you want to perform. How intuitive the app is. How easy it is to perform common operations.
While the UI here is not the best, as I mentioned, it's comparable to modern Indie games.
The UX, on the other hand, feels very very dated. Even for a 2013 game IMO.
Buying, selling or swapping weapons is not very intuitive. And the game menus are not very well thought out.
For example, it takes roughly 6 clicks between different menus to switch a weapon or an item in your inventory.
And it can only be done in your stash, or while talking to a vendor (any vendor in the game). But not anywhere else.
Also, your item list is not very well organized. 
Sometimes you have a huge list of all the items. Sometimes there are filters by item types. There is uniformity.


RPG
The RPG elements of this game, are a mixed lot.
On the one hand, any specific magical / weapon / armor path you choose to progress on, has very little progression.
You will only be able to get 3/4 progressively better item times for the entirety of the game.
On the other hand, there is a really decent variety of different tech/magical paths to choose from.
There are 4 ranged weapon paths, 1 melee weapons path, 1 thrown weapons path, 1 battle droids path
Around 4 different magical spell paths
Physical body augmentation path
And a "hacking" path
And most of the things can be combined together, so you can both have cool weapon, a battle droid and summon a magical being, all in a single battle. (The only exception being physical body augmentation, which affect your magical abilities).
The skill upgrade points (they're called Karma points) are plentiful, you get them quite often - and can easily progress on any path you'd like (Although maxing out any path would be difficult, as they obviously need more and more points for high levels)

The good thing about this, is even though I'm entering this whole new world of D&D-style game. It doesn't feel overbearing. There are not dozens of classes and magical paths to choose from. There is no need to restart the game 3 times to create a decent character.
Everything is pretty clear and straightforward once you start the character creation.
And it's pretty easy to change the character focus on pretty much anything you like.

The difficulty of the game is pretty decent.
Except for the end game, which I found to be super hard (even on easy difficulty).
And required me multiple game re-loads to finish.


BATTLES
The battles are done in turn-based RPG style.
Many weapons have multiple fire-mode types, which increase with higher level of weapon proficiency (i.e. spending skill points).
And hit percentages on every shot.
There are also items that give you partial or full cover (in the tradition of X-COM games).
Throwing grenades also have percentage chances, which define how close to it's target point the grenade will land.

An additional form of battles you have, and hacking/virtual battles.
Which are even more simplistic than regular battles.
And have less variety of weapons and attack types.


PLOT / STORY / WHY YOU SHOULD DEFINITELY PLAY THIS GAME
At this point you must be wondering what's wrong with me...
I've basically described a game which is mediocre at best. And it's 10 years old to boot.
So why would I play this game? For over 20 hours? And even claim you "100% need to play it" ???
Well the game plot/story is why.

The story is simply superb.
From the beginning of the game, to the very end, you're gripped by the mystery, trying to understand who should you trust, who's out to get you, and who is the real killer ???
I'm coming to this game in the heels of playing The Outer Worlds (https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198014150309/recommended/578650/), which had everything this game doesn't.
Amazing graphics. Amazing interfaces. Amazing weapon customizability and progression. But lacked the one thing this game does amazingly well - the plot/story.
The story is mainly told by text.
Both via dialog, and small remarks about how the characters look, act and feel.
It basically feels like a very very good Sci-Fi/Fantasy book, told via the medium of computer games (with some Turn-based battle scenes sprinkled in).
Not just that the plot of the game is good. It's the writing.
The game is very very well written. From the plot, to the dialogs, to the small easter eggs or humor you see here and there.

There is not much in the sense of side-quests in the game.
There are a few, and they add some flavor, but very very little compared to modern RPG games (that have much more side-quests than the main quest).
However even the small side-quests and dialogs there are, make the world feel very much alive and vibrant.

142245162.review:
Pros:
1. Well-written story with intriguing twists.
2. Unique setting combining sci-fi and fantasy elements.
3. Tactical combat with depth and variety.
4. Effective visual style creating a compelling atmosphere.

Cons:
1. Limited choices and linear progression.
2. Simplistic character development and lack of depth in team members.

Overall, "Shadowrun Returns" is a solid isometric RPG with a captivating story and engaging combat. However, its limited scope and choices make it more appealing to see how the community expands upon it with mod tools.

142190822.review:
Shadowrun Returns is a shining gem in the world of modern RPGs, blending cyberpunk aesthetics with fantasy elements to create a unique and captivating experience. From the moment you dive into the dark and gritty world of Shadowrun, you know you're in for a treat.

First and foremost, the storytelling in Shadowrun Returns is top-notch. The game is crafted with love and attention to detail, immersing you in a rich and complex narrative that keeps you hooked from start to finish. The writing is sharp, witty, and filled with twists and turns that will leave you guessing until the very end. As you navigate the neon-lit streets of the future, every dialogue choice feels meaningful, and your decisions have real consequences, shaping the outcome of the tale.

The game's art style is a feast for the eyes. The cyberpunk cityscapes, dark alleys, and futuristic interiors are beautifully rendered, creating an atmosphere that oozes with a distinct blend of technology and magic. Each environment feels alive, bustling with detail and hints of the stories that lie within its shadows. The character designs are equally impressive, with diverse and interesting NPCs populating this gritty world.

Gameplay in Shadowrun Returns strikes a perfect balance between strategy and action. The turn-based combat system is a joy to engage with, offering tactical depth that challenges your decision-making skills. As you assemble a team of skilled shadowrunners, each with unique abilities and roles, you'll find yourself planning and executing intricate strategies to outwit your enemies. It's a satisfying experience to see your plans unfold flawlessly or adapt quickly when things take an unexpected turn.

Furthermore, the character progression system is brilliantly designed. As you earn experience points, you can customize your character with various skills, attributes, and cybernetic enhancements. This freedom allows you to craft your own playstyle, be it a tech-savvy decker, a magical adept, or a lethal gunslinger. The choices you make in character development add depth to your role-playing experience, making every playthrough feel fresh and exciting.

What truly elevates Shadowrun Returns is its dedicated modding community. The game comes with an accessible editor that allows players to create their own campaigns, adding to the already robust replay value. Countless user-generated stories are available to download, expanding the game's universe and ensuring you'll never run out of thrilling adventures to embark on.

In conclusion, Shadowrun Returns is a masterclass in storytelling, art direction, and tactical gameplay. It brilliantly revitalizes the beloved cyberpunk-fantasy tabletop universe and presents it in a way that captivates both fans and newcomers alike. If you have a penchant for engaging narratives, strategic combat, and a world where futuristic technology meets ancient magic, then Shadowrun Returns is an absolute must-play. Step into the shadows and embrace the darkness; you won't regret it.

141570719.review:
This review of mine is pretty late in coming, I know.  I have been a fan of the Shadowrun IP for many years.  When I heard that it was going to be resurrected in the form of a PC game after being a fan of the Sega Genesis Shadowrun game, I was super-excited.
Many years later, I've attempted to enjoy Shadowrun Returns on multiple occasions, and I haven't been successful.
It puts me to sleep.
If you favor story-driven games that require a lot of reading (and I've done my fair share of reading, mind you; I am old-school to the point of having gamed for many years before voice acting in games was even technically possible) and aren't heavy on gameplay, then maybe Shadowrun Returns is a game for you. 

It's not for me; I really wish it were, but after my fourth uninstall without getting more than a couple hours in, I can honestly say it's just not.

Objectively speaking, I give it a thumbs-down not only because it's not for me, but because when you stack it up against other RPGs with tactical combat that have come out before and since Shadowrun Returns's release, it simply doesn't hold a candle and is fairly boring.  Tactical consideration during combat don't go far beyond "well, I specced my guy as a melee dude, so...  I guess I'll get close and pummel the enemy while my caster people stay in the rear and cast spells."  At least in the main campaign that is supplied with the base Shadowrun Returns game (I can't speak for modded campaigns), exploration outside of combat is fairly tedious; it isn't always clear what's expected of you, and there isn't much offered in the way of venturing outside of the "beaten path" as it were.  

One positive that I can offer is that the game does adhere to the lore and world of Shadowrun and does portray them very well.  The artwork of the city streets is nice and colorful and manages to be dark and gritty without being overly grim.  But I just couldn't fight off drowsiness long enough to see the story through.  I should disclose that I haven't been much of a video game story person for a while now (probably since..... Dragon Age Origins and Star Wars: The Old Republic, though I thought Ni No Kuni was pretty cool), but if the gameplay were fun enough, that shouldn't be a problem anyway.

I dunno; it's not that my expectations were super high, and I believe I'm being fairly objective when I say that this just isn't that good a game.  It hasn't aged well, it never really got me very excited to begin with, and I'm done with trying to like it.  I'm somewhat surprised that it's gotten the positive reception that it has.

140772192.review:
Overall it's a decent, solid game with very few bugs.  No game is entirely bug free, but I didn't notice any in my playthrough.

But it does have some extremely annoying mechanics that would've dropped its rating down from 4 to 5 stars to probably 3 stars.  (I really do not like this horrible "all or nothing"  review system Steam has.  Having this binary thumbs up/thumbs down system doesn't allow any nuance - there can't be any "in between."  You either like the game 100% or dislike it 100%.  And that's a big reason why I very rarely write reviews).

The first highly annoying mechanic is how Heal spells work.  If you play a mage or bring one with you, then you might as well dump your Heal spells roughly halfway through the game.  Here's why.

The stupid Heal spell will only heal the damage you took from the last attack that damaged you.  I guess the game just HAD to be different - and couldn't just have Heal spells heal a base amount of damage modified by the level of Heal spell, your Spellcasting skill and your Willpower skill.  Simple as that.  Although I guess the level of spell won't matter since I never found a Level II or higher Healing spell.  I guess that was for the best considering how crappy they are. 

This kind of mechanic is especially frustrating since the AI likes to attack YOU - the player.  Thus your character will often be shot at and cast upon multiple times.  So if you lose 30 health from the first attack and 5 points from a weak pistol shot immmediately thereafter - the Heal spell will only give you back 5 points.  Yeah.  5.  That's it.  Stupid, right?

It gets worse.  Because damage taken from a friggin'  DOT counts as an attack even if you weren't actually attacked or hit by anything.   And there will come a point when everything is trying to DOT you.  The game is trying to chew through your resources so you have nothing left for the final battle.  And it works.   Thus, when you have some annoying DOT sucking away your health, you have no way to cure it.  So if you think that you can just throw a Heal on yourself when some crappy DOT eats your health down to 10 health - forget it.  The Heal spell will only give you back the damage the DOT took, which is usually a lousy 2 or 3 points of health.  I HATE this mechanic.

It also has a somewhat annoying - omniscient AI that always knows exactly what tile to stand in to avoid getting hit.  AI units don't just run behind a crate and hope for the best - like a real person.  I've seen AI units literally run to stand in an open tile - because LOS was blocked for all of my units.  No one could know to do that - but it does.  That's annoying, but not game-breaking.  I can live with it.

The worst bit with omniscience, however, is when even melee AI units will run past 2 or 3 of my guys to attack me.  The AI just loves to attack your character - because it knows that it doesn't have to defeat your whole team to win.  It just has to defeat you.  And I think that's a lousy superpower for the enemy to have.  It's very much metagaming here and I don't like it at all.  This kind of AI coding harkens back to the earliest days of PC gaming - because the computer always knew that your character was the "weakest link."  Kill it, and the game ends - the AI wins.  Doesn't matter if I have 10,000 runners there with me.  Kill me and that's it.  Older and less sophisticated AIs always beelined right for your character because the game knew it only had to defeat your character to win against all the other characters.  

To make matters worse - instead of the game being sophisticated enough to resurrect you if one of the other runners on your crew has something that can do that - you just die.  Your party members aren't smart enough to say, "Oh, I have an item that can resurrect fellow party members - I should use that right now."  

No.  Everything just goes red.  You get a mission failure message - and you start wondering why the f-ing hell an NPC has a resurrection token in the first place.

138951768.review:
[h1] High Tech, Low Fantasy [/h1]

[b] drek, chummer, nuyen, and omae [/b]

[b] Shadowrun Returns, [/b] is a relatively short science fantasy CRPG providing the roleplaying experience of being a Ghost in the Shell character trapped in a YA urban fantasy world.
Okay, that's not entirely true.

This is a review from a casual RPG player. Be warned.
This game is good enough at curating the Shadowrun experience without it being too streamlined to the point that it could lose its identity.
Speaking of identity, the premise alone is inherently interesting to keep the players hooked to the world.
All the trappings of cyberpunk and fantasy elements are blended together well enough that they don't clash with each other. [b] The game's vibe is solid. [/b] 

Gameplay-wise, it's a competent turn-based combat system, akin to XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Although here, the game's a bit jank, the magic folder UI sometimes come and go according to their mood that day.
The character progression works well, but I did caught my self min-maxing my etiquette. They should've just let the players choose all three in the beginning and stick to them through the playthrough. 
The combat scenarios are competently made, but the game mechanics can trivialize them quite easily. 
If the enemy can't see you, they'll charge forth to find you, without further tactic. I spent good amount of time during combat just funneling them into our overwatch cone of visions and just demolished these guys.

I played as a soldier/hacker a la Motoko Kusanagi, and the game allows me to be as badass as her, although I only specialized in one type of weapon.

Roleplaying-wise, it's very specialized. "Multiclassing" is not optimal in this case. 
If you're a beginner, you should focused on playing an archetype first. Once you know how the game works, then that's when you can mix it up a little bit. There's even an option to customize your own archetype.
The character creator is good enough. Healthy amount of race types to play as. 
Visually, the character customization is fairly limited, which is fine.  
The skill checks are fun. Investing in stats is mostly useful.
Oh, you'll meet some fun characters along the way. They're good, not great.


Any hard negatives?

No voice acting. This is more of my problem, having an attention span of a cat. 

Since no voice acting, a lot of reading. If this turns you off, I can empathize. 
But to be fair, the prose is not exactly great, like it's okay. Spelling mistakes here and there. Unintentional, I reckon. And the way they present the texts are very intimidating length-wise. Hard to digest them sometimes.

The pseudo-Japanese 'omae' slang. It's not bad, it's just funny. 

The game is good for what it is.
Really enjoyed my time as a fantacyberpunk.
A solid first game for the trilogy. Could've been better, and it'll get better later.
Fairly cheap as well these days.
Also, Coyote's a beast, man.

138021746.review:
The archetypes such as Decker and Mage available at character creation simply assign the majority of your Karma for you. If you want full control over creating your character, it's better not to pick one.

Etiquettes aren't particularly useful in the Dead Man's Switch base campaign, but Academic will net you a decent chunk of cash early on while Shadowrunner and Corporate will come up the most often.

Don't ignore skill bonuses given by outfits. For example a Rigger will gain access to the incredibly powerful +2 AP bonus for drones at Drone Combat 9 which can be reduced to 8 by wearing an outfit increasing the skill by 1. Due to the way the skill system works, this single point is worth a whopping 27 Karma.

Conjured spirits have a chance to go berserk at the end of each turn, so it's best to keep them away from your party and close to the enemy to make sure the spirit goes after them first should you get unlucky.

Action Points are the most valuable resource in combat, so boosting your AP with things like the Haste spell while reducing the enemies' AP with things like concussion grenades can give a large edge in combat.

Ranged Combat 3 (or Melee Combat 3) opens up your third weapon slot. This is especially useful for Rigger/Deckers who need three slots for a cyberdeck and two drones.

While specialization is generally recommended, lightly dipping into other skills is cheap and often effective. A Shaman can expand their options by getting some Mage spells for example.

Cyberware hugely hinders a character's magical abilities. A physical class equipped with cyberware can consider some light investment in magic in order to gain access to simple buffs or magical healing, but on the opposite end pure spellcasters should avoid cyberware entirely.

Unlike all other weapons in the game, sniper rifles get less accurate the closer you are to the enemy.
The highest-end guns in the game all utilize a Smartlink. When choosing cyberware, make sure you have a datajack if you want to take advantage of this.

Good Indie game, cyberpunk theme. Very cool

137970406.review:
Shadowrun Returns is an great isometric turn-based RPG with a vast amount of lore behind it. Lovely! 
 
[b]❤️️ Pros ❤️️[/b]
[list]
[*]The game is based on the already established Shadowrun universe. Because of that, there is a lot of lore in place already allowing for great depth and detail in the world that you play in. 
[*]The story is good, albeit a little bit predictable. Even though you know what is coming, it is interesting enough to see how everything unfolds. 
[*]Graphics are okay - together with the music they really set the tone to create a cyberpunk-like ambience, but no amazing graphics card needed here. 
[*]Gameplay is alright - don't expect huge depth here, but it feels like an "XCOM Lite". There's cover and RNG when it comes to hitting your target, but it doesn't go much deeper than that. Enemy AI isn't that smart, generally they run up to you and attack.  
[*]There are uniquely named classes, such as the "Street Samurai" and the "Decker" which brings a little diversity to the standard Warrior/Mage/Thief standards.
[/list]

[b]❌ Cons ❌[/b]
[list]
[*]There is no spoken dialogue. For a game that's very dialogue-heavy (basically, outside of combat you are talking) this felt like a missed opportunity. The game was funded through a (very successful) kickstarter campaign and that might have made it harder to find good voice actors, but that doesn't make it less boring. 
[*]The game is linear. There are optional quests but they are nothing more than a single-map side quest, to then continue down the line that the main quest has laid out for you. Nothing you choose at the start of the game (race/gender/class) affects what you'll end up seeing, besides some dialogue changes. There is an illusion of choice, but no matter how good or evil you are, you always end up going down the same path. 
[*]It's not a very long game. I heard that the other games in the trilogy were longer, but don't expect this game to take more than 20 hours.

[/list]

[b]Final thoughts[/b]
Shadowrun Returns is a good (re)introduction to the Shadowrun universe. While it's not an outstanding game, I'd recommend playing it for the cool lore. Definitely consider getting it on a sale.

137245641.review:
Shadowrun Returns is a turn-based RPG game set in a dystopian cyberpunk world. While the game's premise may sound interesting, it ultimately falls short and fails to deliver a satisfying gaming experience.

One of the biggest issues with the game is its lack of depth and complexity. The game's story is forgettable, with unmemorable characters and a plot that fails to engage the player. The game's dialogue is also lackluster, with uninspired writing and flat voice acting that fails to bring the characters to life.

The game's combat system can feel repetitive and uninspired, with limited tactical options and a lack of variety in enemies and weapons. The game's leveling and progression systems are also lackluster, with little variety in skills and abilities.

The game's graphics are also outdated and lackluster, with poorly designed character models and uninspired environments that feel lifeless and uninteresting. The game's sound design is also subpar, with repetitive sound effects and forgettable music that fails to add to the game's atmosphere.

Overall, while Shadowrun Returns may appeal to fans of the RPG genre, it is not a game that I can recommend. Its lack of depth and complexity, forgettable story and characters, uninspired combat and leveling systems, outdated graphics, and subpar sound design make it a disappointing experience that fails to live up to its potential

Shadowrun Returns es un juego de rol táctico con combates por turnos ambientado en un futuro distópico en el que la tecnología y la magia conviven. Como jugador, encarnas a un Shadowrunner, un mercenario que se mueve por los bajos fondos para cumplir misiones, ya sea por dinero o por la necesidad de ayudar a la gente con la que te vas encontrando. La personalización de tu personaje puede ser muy variada, lo cual te permite hacer combinaciones muy interesantes y que se adapten al estilo de juego que busques, ya sea cuerpo a cuerpo, magia o combate a distancia.

Te vas encontrado con una serie de personajes muy interesantes a lo largo de la campaña. Uno de los personajes que más me ha gustado ha sido Arlequín, aunque no entraré en detalles para no revelar nada de la trama, sólo diré que cada personaje tiene una personalidad y una manera de expresarse muy bien hecha, lo cual ayuda a la inmersión y a querer saber más, tanto de la trama como de los mismos personajes.

A nivel técnico, no he tenido ningún problema durante mi experiencia de juego. El juego se desarrolla de forma fluida y sin ningún bug que haya afectado negativamente a mi experiencia de juego.

Los gráficos y la ambientación del juego son muy bonitos, y reflejan muy bien la atmósfera cyberpunk del universo de Shadowrun. La música también es destacable, con temas pegadizos y bien compuestos que ayudan a meterte en la piel de un Shadowrunner.

En general, Shadowrun Returns me ha parecido un juego muy interesante y entretenido para los amantes del RPG y del combate por turnos al estilo de los clásicos Fallout y Fallout 2. Lo recomiendo sin duda a todos aquellos que busquen una experiencia de juego diferente y original.

The game is an isometric RPG with simplified XCOM like combat. The world is the most fleshed out part of the game, the story is interesting but simple. The RPG elements, (dialogue choices, character builds) are varied but don't feel finished enough to make a huge difference in narrative or gameplay. I played my character for head-cannon over min maxing anything and enjoyed it. The combat is fun, though the many varied options of items, spells, gun types, gun abilities and character job specific abilities are all as effective as each other really so I never needed to focus on specific builds or combat strategies beyond the most basic. Gameplay wise each area and story section has some interesting world exploration to it, and some light choices that can affect how you approach a fight. 

    If it feels like I am damning with faint praise, I don't mean to. This game is obviously a labour of love. If some of the games systems feel like they could be improved upon, well,.. that's what the sequels are for.

It's too short. It's too one-dimensional. There's no other way around it. I loved the SNES and Genesis games, but somehow this game manages to be even more barebones than them.

I watched a full, albeit condensed playthrough of the game on Youtube a few years ago. While the story was charming and the gameplay at its core was fun, I decided I'd probably never actually play it.

Well, here I am, years later, and I tried to actually play it. I got halfway through the game.

My opinion changed literally zero from when I watched the full (eight-hour) playthrough on Youtube:

It's a very simplistic tactical RPG in the vein of X-COM.

- The gameplay is extremely one-dimensional
- It's linear to the point of being flawed
- There's NO voice-acting whatsoever
- There are still several bugs that persist
- Bloated skill tree, many underpowered skills
- QoL and interface issues such as: needing to go downstairs to your stash to save equipment, no tips in UI or pop-up advice, not being able to exit combat mode yet not knowing where enemies are (for example summoned spirits can turn against you without you knowing)

Even for an indie title, it just isn't worth it. The story and characters are charming, and the combat is fun at first, but I would just give this one a hard pass at any price point. I hear the two sequels are better, and I will go into them without having previously watched a playthrough.

130278107.review:
Shadowrun Returns

A short 8~ hour-long highly linear isometric turn-based RPG.

It's- alright. I suppose, in 2013, it might've been great; but given how we've had so many phenomenal RPGs since 2013, Shadowrun Returns does fail to hold up a tad. The visual are- admittedly, still good; though the character models are a bit jank. The combat is very simplistic; it's just the standard "use cover, then shoot at the enemy as often as you can", and occasionally casting spells. Nothing particularly outstanding- it's acceptable, really. Consider this a /tentative/ recommendation. If you want a short RPG that isn't a 50-hour grinder, you can certainly still find better short RPGs, but this isn't necessarily something to completely skip over either.

My biggest complaint; though, is that some of the builds are woefully... Underserved? Like, Decking for example, it's basically the "hacker" build; where you get transported into a neat little cyberspace area and fight intrusion countermeasures and other hackers to gain access to security systems, system logs, unlocking doors; etc.

The problem is, decking really only gets seriously used in 2~ missions; making it an INCREDIBLY expensive investment; and for those two missions, you'll usually be given a high-quality decker for cheap/free. It... Does feel a bit scuffed in that regard. Decking also usually isn't very "interactive" with the environment? For example, in one mission- there actually ARE turrets you can hack- and it's the only mission. All other decking interactiveness is usually just "unlocks door leading to exit" or "unlocks the exit itself", occasionally you'll get some lore scraps through it- and there ARE a few decking checks throughout the game that aren't actual hacking and just dialogue options; but they're so few and far between; and so lacking in serious use that it really does suck.

Riggers, on the other hand- are drone users, and they are served a LOT. Most missions, especially later on; you'll find TONS of shafts that only the Rigger drones can access- and Riggers are also HILARIOUSLY powerful; especially as you level up even higher. To the point where you can dish out over 160 damage per turn, which- is enough to kill literally everything EXCEPT the final boss in a single turn. Most other classes generally don't compare in sheer damage output.

Other archetypes/classes exist; and they're all somewhat middling.

Leveling!

You'll only gain enough "Karma" (skill points) to seriously max out three skills and pick two to dump a few points into- for my character, it was Intelligence, which is the core stat for Rigging, which I also maxxed, and Drone Combat, which is a subskill of Rigging. Then, I put points into Body for survivability, and tossed in like two extra levels into Charisma for no particular reason.

The story itself is pretty good. Nothing particularly "wow-y", and none of the characters are *particularly* memorable, which sucks. The missions are all fairly standard; a mix of combat, general environment interaction, and investigation; given the story happens to be a murder mystery (That, for what it's worth, gets solved like... Halfway through the entire game, and the other half is just chasing down the murderer). The story is VERY linear though. You essentially can't veer off the road in the slightest; and in a manner, it is a tad frustrating. Most dialogue options all generally lead to the same-ish outcome, and there is only ONE side mission, which is a pure-combat arena that ends fairly quickly and whose reward isn't even really worth the amount of money you're spending on hiring your crew.

One thing of note; this game /apparently/ supports a high-quality campaign creator and has a ton of workshop support for it. I haven't personally tried it out; but it SEEMS fairly expansive, and there is a decent bit of stuff on the workshop. If the main story doesn't interest you; there's plenty of player-made custom campaigns in the workshop, it seems.

As for bugs? The game, as far as I was able to tell; only has one- and it's during the UB infiltration mission where you have to put on some janitor clothes. In one of the closets- theres an option to pick up a keycard, and another option to pick up a dwarf's uniform. I wrongly assumed every closet would have a keycard, so I didn't pick it up. HOWEVER, if you close out of the interaction menu- the locker is NO LONGER AVAILABLE for interacting, so make sure to pick up the keycard, and THEN go and find a uniform that fits your character.

Still, despite all that; for a game that REGULARLY goes on sale for... Like $2- it's more than worth it for a short RPG you can complete in like two-three sittings, with a solid beginning, middle, and end that all cleanly wraps up and doesn't leave any real plot threads/loose ends. Plus, it STILL looks great; aside from the awkward stiffness of the character models.

129321954.review:
Shadowrun Returns is a great introduction to the world of Shadowrun. It's based primarily in 3d edition Shadowrun, so if you're a TTRPG player who has been playing in 5th ed or 6th World then this is going to look pretty different. No technomancy, fewer Adept specialties, and the differences between Shamans and Mages are more rigid. That said, you can go with an archetype or completely make a character from scratch using simplified 3rd ed rules (which is pretty fun if you want that nostalgia hit). The campaign is short (8-10 hours on average), but there are lots of excellent UGCs in the workshop to play, you can make your own games using the resources, and some dedicated players have updated all kinds of resources and campaign modules from 1st-3rd edition in the workshop. There's a lot more to do than just the base campaign. 

SRR is set in Seattle, one of the primary campaign settings for the TTRPG. The story is part fantasy, part cyber-punk, part Neo-Noir, and the right amount of goofy to be entertaining. SRR also retains a more accurate depiction of how hacking worked in earlier editions with opposed checks and IC warfare. This was changed in Hong Kong to a more real-time matching game (which is punishing if you're not good at that style of game). The user console can be used for QoL or to experiment with different karma builds (it can also help if there's a glitch). This world is intentionally dark. You're not a hero out to save the world in this game. You're trying to live from minute to minute in a world that is trying quite hard to ignore your existence or go out of its way to kill you.

Negatives: None of the Shadowrun games have an accurate hit accuracy calculations for shotguns. Don't expect to hit anything standing in front of you even with high stats. It's a bit of an inside joke with the series.  The game is older and can be a bit glitchy on Windows 11 at times. Recommended to run it in full screen to avoid issues and saving often (keep multiple saves too since you can get locked into some runs and find yourself unable to proceed if you're karma is too low). Controller support is almost unusable. It really only works for panning the camera. You still have to use the mouse to select tiles to move to, zoom distances, and dialog choices. Even with third party controller interfaces it's just not worth it. The music can be very loud and the sound levels are different in the main menu versus in the game itself. Be careful when wearing headphones. The hit box for moving to a tile versus interacting with an object on an adjacent tile can be misleading. You might lose a turn if you're not careful in combat. Keep that in mind when you go to move or attack/interact that you have to be very centered on what you're clicking on. Zoom in if in doubt.

Final Verdict: Definitely recommended.

Notes: I own the original Kickstarter editions of all three games. Depending on what the current Steam version is of SRR, you may open the game and have it say it's "Dragonfall". If so, you have both games in one. If it says "Shadowrun Returns" then you will need to get Dragonfall separately if you want to play both games (some UGCs require both). Hong Kong is always separate and the extended edition of that is recommended since the ending falls a bit flat otherwise.

124599998.review:
[h1] Short but sweet, and a great introduction to the Shadowrun universe [/h1]

[b]Shadowrun Returns[/b] is a linear party-based RPG with "tactical" style turn based combat taking place in the Shadowrun universe, which is cyberpunk mixed with fantasy elements (elves, dragons, etc.).  It's a fun setting, and the game does a great job at introducing it.
[hr][/hr]
What's immediately striking about the game is the excellent soundtrack and wonderful hand-painted backgrounds and character portraits.  These all come together to set a great mood.  Less impressive are the 3D models for characters and enemies, but they get the job done.

The game is extremely linear, with you being taken from one mission to the next with a small base of operations to visit in between missions, where you can purchase equipment and hire the rest of your team.  There really aren't that many options for equipment, so you quickly end up getting top level gear halfway through the game.  Luckily, the game is paced quite well with experience point ("karma") rewards during and after missions, so you won't be maxing anything out until the very end of the game (especially if you are playing as a hybrid class).

The combat works fine and is "tactical" in the sense that you have more options in battle than in most other RPGs.  You can take cover behind things for defense bonuses, select different fire modes for your guns, and make use of all sorts of spells including summons.  Having said that, combat is not very difficult at all on the default difficulty level, and it's mostly enough to just stay in cover and make sure to reload whenever you have a chance.

There is a heavy focus on story and dialog, though the text is generally well-written and not overly verbose.  I enjoyed the story, but it will all depend on whether you find the unique setting to be fun or too goofy to take seriously.  What's even better, is that certain dialog options will only be available if you have spent enough points in certain attributes/skills.  It would probably be fun to replay the game as a totally different type of character.
[hr][/hr]
Although I enjoyed the game, there were a few things I didn't like.

I don't mind a linear game, but I do wish you had the choice of doing some optional missions in between story missions.  I was also unpleasantly surprised at how few equipment upgrades there are; I continued to use my starting shotgun for nearly half the game, and only upgraded to a better one for the last couple of missions.
[hr][/hr]
Having said that, these are only minor complaints for what is overall an enjoyable little game.  The sequels are apparently much bigger games with lots of optional content, so I'm definitely looking forward to them.  Highly recommended, especially if you find the setting and theme to be interesting.

123462678.review:
relatively short fun isometric  strategy/rpg title. 
the story moves through the missions. in this regard this game is closer to any strategy game campaign, like, say, starcraft, where you are locked inside each mission and can't go back or decide the order of doing things in your walkthrough, rather then rpg titles like baldur's gate, where you have an open world to explore. 
shadowrun has very little side quests, so you are basically going through main quest from start to finish, occasionally taking side jobs, when they are available.
the plot itself is absurd but somewhat charming and, most importantly, it opens an  opportunity for implementing unique game mechanics, and we all gathered here for the gameplay, right?
shadowrun has a mix of genres thrown together and tossed hard: it is a fantasy, but also a cyberpunk universe, it has magic, and technology, and shamanism, and shi-fi elements, and everything is written like a noir mystery novel. if you are looking for a literature masterpiece, you probably will be disappointed, but if you don't mind a bit of corny and wacky for sake of entertainment, give it a try.
now for the good stuff: gameplay. you have your turn-based fights, 3 actions per turn, a decent range of weapons, several type of magic including summoning spirits, and hacking. if the mission has a hacking part it is the most fun. you need to make sure your hacker arrived safely to the spot where he can connect to the matrix and defend him, while he acts inside the matrix. so you have a 2-dimensional stage of events, where you switch between the matrix and the real world - never played anything like that.
the rpg parts are pretty unique too. you earn karma points for the missions and spend those for your stats and skills. the further you go to the certain tree, the more expensive is the next step, however you have a lot of room for the experimentation, you have enough karma to make anything from any class you started with,  from a decent jack of all trades to a glasscanon (me every time lol). 
despite being an old and somewhat unforgiving game (no, you can't re-speck) the in-game instructions on classes ans karma are very good. you can build a character and complete the game just using provided info, no need of reading 1000s of pages of guides on making a character (looking at you, underrail)
the game itself has only 1 campaign, but if you want more, there is plenty additional missions at steam workshop.
overall, nice game, can be enjoyable, can be frustrating, can be beaten in a couple of evenings

I return to Shadowrun Returns (oh snap, what a pun!) after couple of years… with the intention to replay the whole trilogy. Gotta start with the first one, that’s obvious. 

“Returns” is a … foundation. Good template. It’s very limited, linear RPG, lacking any meaningful sidequesting - and you can easily finish it in 6-7 hours. From perspective we know that this foundation led to better, more fleshed out sequels - Dragonfall and Hong Kong.

Still, it’s not right to omit Shadowrun Returns. The story is interesting, serves as a great introduction to wonderful, cyberpunk world of Shadowrun. In terms of mechanics, it’s competent and enjoyable enough. Soundtrack is full of bangers. Yes, it’s very small scale and simplified as a RPG… but still a lot of fun. 

Maybe “Returns” does not stand its own as a separate game …but as a part of a trilogy… it’s a helluva first act.

122613876.review:
This is kind of a weird review for me. I first played this game near it's initial release at the end of 2013 and got pretty significantly far through the game, and then did not play it again for almost 9 years until a random night this month where I redownloaded it and completed the game, after having given the series thought over the past several years but never re-engaging.

Shadowrun Returns is a tactical turn based RPG in a cyberpunk-fantasy setting based on a popular tabletop RPG.
The setting is a little ridiculous in the sense that it attempts to combine high-magic fantasy including elves, orcs, and mages alongside the cyberpunk trappings of high tech, body modification, and matrix-style mental interaction with the internet. It's a weird juxtaposition and honestly, it often doesn't make sense, but it's something I really enjoy and is the main highlight of a game like this.

The gameplay is a very typical CRPG top down perspective kind of thing with tactical turn based combat with basic point and click controls for when you're out of combat.
To be honest I'm not a huge fan of this sort of gameplay. I don't particularly care for tactical RPGs, especially when they try to make their reputation for having combat that is 'brutal' and 'unforgiving' and in addition to that it just seems incredibly disjointed for a game that tries to have elements of exploration and story interaction, that is often bogged down by having to interact with those things in a turn-based, tactical system.

The story however, while not stellar, is pretty good, and serves as a good introduction to the Shadowrun universe, which is what I believe the developers were hoping for. To be honest the story itself kinda glides over me most of the time while playing this but it serves to just expose me to the cool setting. Which is what I really want.
Similarly, the art, is not necessarily that exceptional, but it absolutely serves its purpose in immersing you further into this setting and communicating the tone and feel of this world that you're playing in.
I can say the same thing about the soundtrack as well.

Overall, if you want a cool exposure to the Shadowrun universe, and are willing to slog through some uninteresting combat to do so, I would absolutely recommend this game. If you don't have much of a tolerance for those things, or if you're hoping for a deeper experience story wise. I can't say I do. But for me it gets a thumbs up.

122043453.review:
A human mage, elf decker and troll shaman walk into a bar...

[i]Shadowrun Returns[/i] is a tactical role-playing game developed by Harebrained Schemes and published by Paradox Interactive.

[b]Story[/b]
Game takes place in a science fantasy setting of a Shadowrun tabletop role-playing game.
Your character is a shadowrunner who gets a pre recorded message from old friend Sam triggered by Dead Man's Switch inside his body. Declaring his death by a murder, he wants you to find out who killed him and bring justice. This calls for a trip to Seattle, where you will have to deal with mysterious Emerald City Ripper and his murder spree.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Returns is an isometric, turn-based title, featuring linear gameplay with small and medium sized areas you travel through to complete objectives and push story further.

Before you actually get into a game, you have to create a character! So first you pick prefered race and optionally, an archtype. Here we have fantasy classics with futuristic spin. You can focus on killing things with melee or ranged weapons, utilize technology to control deadly drones and hack different elements, or use magic to kill enemies and buff your allies.
You are also free to go for mixing different types together for hybrid builds, good at both but great at neither.

Once that is over you can start enjoying a game, location by location, in a rather uncommon for RPG's combination as most of them tends to go for open world approach.
While making your way through the areas you can interract with few items, including NPC's who might give you a side quest or two, and enviroment, usually different lockers and crates containing items.
Game features only one location you constantly revisit, which serves as a hub where you can restock your supplies, buy and sell your equipment or hire few mercenaries for your party, for more combat focused bits.
Game uses nuyens as credits, you can collect them through exploration and objectives completion. You cannot collect such elements as weapons or armor in the field, so don't be shy on spending them!

And it's definitely worth to spend those hard earned nuyens, as combat won't be screwing around with you.
It's a typical turn based one, you and each member of your party has a specific amount of action points to spend during a turn and it is your call on how you waste them. Moving, reloading a weapon, utilizing items, every action costs.
After done turn, your enemies do their move, occasionally there are also neutral opponents on a field doing their moves too.
Goal in combat is to not get killed, and if you fail you have to use a revival kit in specific amount of turns, or your character dies forever-ever, and that would suck.
Game features classic percentage system, so every action that is performed on enemy, from typical weapon shot to magic spell, has X percent of chance to hit. You gonna miss 80% shots and sometimes hit 50%, that is how those games roll and how my eyes roll sometimes when I play them and miss those high percentage ones.

When it comes to equipment, it's depending on your character, but no matter who you play as, you have option of storing few items with you that can be wasted during or in-between combat, such as medkits, and everyone can wear some sort of clothing to provide better Armor. Additionally, if you on your journey find a usable item and your equipment is full, you can send it to a Stash in hub location to exchange or pick it later! Rest of items is dependable on class.

Shadowrun doesn't feature xp system. Instead, by completing objectives and quests you recieve Karma, which can be spend on skills in a menu.
Skills don't stand out, you have few focused on specific playstyle you took and they branch out, plus few universal ones like Charisma. Amount of Karma you need for a skill depends on it's level. To unlock 5th Charisma level you will need 5 Karma, to make an example.

[b]Playtime, replayability and other modes[/b]
Game took me 8 hours to complete.
If you were a fan of the combat and want to try out different playstyle in it, you can give this title another spin.
Outside of main campaign game comes with, you can look for user generated ones which can be found and downloaded from the internet! So if you want more Shadowrun, you can dig a bit to find some user made content to increase your playtime.

[b]Pros and cons[/b]
Shadowrun's science fantasy setting is definitely what got me interested in a game, and one of strongest points of it. I'm surprised by how well fantasy elements have been intergrated into this futuristic settting, and how you can enjoy dropping fireballs as an elf mage or hack different systems as a rogue dwarf and it feels ordinary. While I am a bit dissapointed about linear approach to a world design, what is here is very good and I hope it works as a great foundation for other games to build on.
Additionally we have simple but enjoyable turn based combat, decent variety of locations you explore on your way, and solid roster of interesting characters you encounter. Easy navigation and equipment menu means that even if you are not into isometric crpg's you will have a very easy time figuring all mechanics out.

Negatives! Unfortunately linear design and massive amount of skill trees don't go hand in hand. My biggest issue is that game doesn't offer a lot of secondary options when it comes to beating the areas like usual, more open world titles do. Don't get me wrong, you can, every once in a while, use Charisma or some hacking skill to find an alternative way through a location, or to gain more credits from an action, but for the most part it's just guns blazing that game pulls out.
Skill trees are simply to freaking packed to actually be coherent with what game offers. You have to be from the start, very decisive about your Karma usage, let me put it that way.
This connects to previous issue in very simple way, some skill tress are utterly useless in the game and just a waste of Karma, giving you a false sense of bigger amount of options. So I think, or rather I hope, that next entry of Shadowrun which I will play sooner or later, has reworked skill system or simply changes approach to locations in order to give player more freedom and reason to look into some of the options it offers.

[b]Final words and conclusion[/b]
Director's Cut offers you Soundtrack and illustrated PDF of short stories written and edited by Jordan Weisman, the creator of Shadowrun!

Shadowrun Returns with uncommon science fantasy setting and good gameplay is a title worthy of playing, and a solid starting point for those interested in Shadowrun universe.

Check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31947302/] my curator page [/url] for more reviews!

120998645.review:
Shadowrun Returns is a mobile ported lightweight RPG set in the Shadowrun universe of Orcs, magic, cyberware and guns.  We all love venerable RPG properties like Battletech, Dungeons and Dragons, Cyberpunk and yes, also, Shadowrun.  But this is a disaster.

I grabbed Shadowrun Returns as soon as I could because I really believed this would be a new Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, Skyrim.  Dungeons and Dragons online.  LOTRO.  World of Warcraft?  It could have been?  It's a rich universe, so why shouldn't game developers treat this with that level of relevance?  Hahaha, no, this is HBS and Paradox.  So this is a mobile app.  It was made for iPhones.  It's dumbed down and thickened up and lightweight as all hell. 

Take the rules for Shadowrun.  Deep and brilliant, right?  Eviscerate them until about 5% of those rules are left.  Dumb them down.  Strap them onto an extremely linear story and a clunky screen tapper mobile interface.   Polish nothing, and test the game only on iPhones.  Ladies and Gentlemen:  I present the result, Shadowrun Returns.  

Adding a severe insult to injury, there's no UI scaling in this mobile app, so if you own a gaming PC, it won't display properly on your UHD display, text will be simply too small to read.  But remember, HBS/Paradox only tested this on mobile phones. 

This game is also ancient, launched in 2013 (But remastered... slightly).  And despite the remaster, they didn't bother making the game well on modern PCs.  And yet.. they still want $15 for this massive disappointment. 

I gave this a solid attempt despite all the problems... I really wanted to believe... but it just got to the point where the shallowness, dumbed down nature of the game felt like a serious insult to both PC gamers and Shadowrun fans.

I know what Paradox would say about this insult... you all have phones, don't you?

I played through this because I have a lot of nostalgia for the old Genesis/SNES Shadowrun games. This newer game (2013, but a lot newer than those old games!) captures the essence of the old game pretty well, although this is a much more focused story. This has good and bad ramifications on the game. The story is interesting and cohesive, but there is much less freedom to do whatever you want that the old game had. One of the major reasons I loved the old games is because you had a loose story, but could branch of into doing whatever. The world felt immersive and did not guide the player too much. 

Here, the story is better but the game loses some of what captured my attention so many years ago. It is not a game of endless possibility that you can get lost in. It feels more like other games and a bit less unique. Even so, I recommend this. Had a fun time playing it throughout. I am not sure it has the replayability to go through a second time though.

117945017.review:
It's a 7/10 from me. It's pretty good as a demo for the rest of the series, but it has a lot of problems. For starters, the inability to rotate the map can make it frustrating to position your teammates. The UI is bad, being unresponsive at times and feeling more like it belongs in a mobile game. The game's very linear and your choices don't matter at all. It's also a very easy game (with a nasty spike in the very final battle), so the simplistic combat can get boring quickly. The level design is decent, I guess - except every Matrix level, those suck. The most egregious aspect, though, has to be how the game doesn't explain you the combat mechanics. How does cover work? What does armor do? Better google it!

But the story, even though it has some pacing issues, is very good! The Sixth World is also fascinating, so this game serves as a neat introduction to the world of Shadowrun. The music is also pretty good and fits the vibes of the game well. The game's short in RPG terms (12 - 14 hours long), but I think that's a good thing! If you can look past the negative aspects, like I can, these basically carry the entire game.

Character Tips:  None of the races are bad and you won't really feel the maximum stat limits in the default campaign.   Samurai is simplest to play and you can almost solo the whole campaign on normal (with some of the default mission teammates.)  Mage & Rigger (turn on drones which become team mates) are also pretty straight-forward, Shaman is good but some limits to summoning based on mission, while Adept can be used but just wasn't implemented well.  I don't recommend Decker as a primary class as 80% of the game is non-VR and the number of times you can hack a turret or something is very limited and simple to accomplish.   You can hire team mates of any class so you can always try them out (you just don't get to pick their specific spells/programs/gear).

Stat Tips:  You'll end up earning a fair number of Karma points thru the game.  Body is important as you'll get targeted a lot and Quickness and Willpower help determine how easy you are to hit with physical and magic attacks respectively.   The majority of attacks will be physical as you'll tend to target and take out enemy mages/shamans quickly.  Make sure you have 3-4 body min and focus on your main stats.   Early stats are cheap so you can shore up a secondary skill or two (like decker) mid-game.   Cha 4 gets you through most skill checks and pick whatever conversation specialties you want.  Action points are the most important stat in the game but you can't control the amount (2 to start, 3 later)  Note that Armor can't go above 10 so factor that in as you look at your gear/cyberware/buffs.   Hit % becomes increasingly more difficult so you'll want to ensure you have plenty of buffs/skills to help.

Gear/Spell Tips:  The game limits your options with the number of weapon, gear, and spell/special ability slots you have available to carry stuff into a mission.  Haste (increase AP) is the single most powerful spell in the game.  Spells have different power levels (1-4 for example) which you'll be able to upgrade as you get stronger and increases impact and/or duration.  You can equip multiple levels of the same spell (Haste 1 and Haste 2) so you can cast one while the other is cooling down.   You get special abilities with weapons as you increase skill and you can see what they are on your Karma increase screen.  All the weapons are workable but Rifle (with the Full Autofire skill at level 3) is probably going to become your mainstay damage dealer if you  have it.   Note: Don't bother with the cyberlink for weapons before the end-game as they only become available in the late missions (also don't get confused with the Ingram "Smartgun" SMG description, the true "linked" weapons are clearly marked).  

Combat Tips:  Manage your AP points carefully, buff your main damage dealers with Haste and Aim so can lay down the hate.  Haste stacks so you can get 5 or more AP without too much difficulty mid-game.   You can also bolster your team with Drones and Summoning.  Armor buff your team but remember the 10 max.  A support mage can/should burn through their entire AP each turn just buffing round-robin through your team.  Take out mage types first and finish off weak enemies as anyone on the board gets their full actions the following turn.   I never really used much gear or any of the drugs in the normal difficulty.  But remember that magic healing only heals the damage from the last attack, so if you take a 10 damage hit followed by a 5 damage, a heal will only restore 5.    It's worth throwing heal spells immediately after damage (topping off) as you may have to burn a first aid kit later if you wait and take another hit.   Overwatch is a great function and appears when you get combat level 4 (range/close).  It allows you to reserve some AP and pick a direction to "cover".  If an enemy enters that area you get a free attack (you can pick things like autofire if you have the 2 AP it costs).   It's a great way to cut down enemies or heavily damage them before your turn starts.   Note it looks like a little wifi symbol in the lower left weapon selection area when it becomes available.

Those are a few things I picked up from the guides and my playthroughs.  Have fun!

113847003.review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
As my first foray into the Shadowrun series I am left less than impressed by Returns. Granted, it's a decade old so I have some leniency, but it does not excel in any way, on top of having a few game design hurdles to overcome and an inherent clunkiness due to its age. I'd like to give it a neutral review as it's not a [i]bad[/i] game and there are things it does well, however whether it's worth playing over its successors or competitors in the genre is arguable at best.

[h1]Story[/h1]
I shall leave the gameplay section for the end as that's where most of my issues come into play. Story-wise you play as a shadowrunner, essentially a mercenary trying to figure out the killer of his late friend. In classic RPG fashion, along the way you get to work with a number of characters, both as  part of your team and as contractors or flavour NPCs. The writing for the main story is alright, although it's not the most memorable, especially once some of the twists come in, but the characters you meet are at least passably written in a believable way that adds some flavour to the world. I especially appreciated being able to talk to the vendors between missions to get a bit more lore out of them but whether I'd consider any to be truly memorable is rather unlikely. In spite of the shortcomings, the worldbuilding is quite fantastic and it servers as a good introduction to the world without making it feel overwhelming.

The story itself is entirely linear and although conversations have dialogue choices, including stat checks, they either don't matter or only affect monetary rewards, rather than give you more options or change the story in any way. Likewise, when it comes to sidequests (if you can call them that), the limited amount of them tend to either be in the way of your objectives due to the linearity of the game, with one exception that represents a separate mission in a new location. These usually boil down to exploring your environment for one of the very few spots you can interact with to find some item or information someone is looking for.

It's worth noting that there are user created content packs for the game, although most seem to be abandoned or moved to Dragonfall instead so I'm not going to cover them. It might give you some extra content if you enjoy the game though.

[h1]Visuals & Audio[/h1]
The visual style is one of the strong points here. Although some of the areas get a little repetitive, it carries a strong isometric art style which lasts the test of time. The game itself has few bells and whistles when it comes to flashy tricks but what's there works and is generally clear enough. One thing I especially appreciated was the variety of default character portraits that matched the look of the character models, making it just that little bit more accurate despite the limited customisation.

Audio-wise there's nothing to write home about. The music serves as a good backdrop for the setting and the sound design is okay for the most part even if a few weapons sound rather underwhelming.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
I'll try to keep this brief. Ignoring the hub and story areas, the main crux of the gameplay consists of turn-based combat with an action economy, backed by gear, consumables, stats and skills - About what you expect from an RPG. There's a mixture of gunplay, melee, minion control in the form of drones and spirits, and spells, most of which functioning analogously for the various classes, although you are by no means restricted by your starting class.

Outside of combat, your choice of loadout is somewhat limited. New gear unlocks throughout the game which is a direct upgrade of its predecessor. If you can go without an upgrade earlier on it'll give you more cash to work with later on, which is ideal. The same goes for all aspects of equipment, being limited to three or four tiers of effectiveness. Your stats and skills are going to be the main point of investment, since those are always going to be useful and as long as you specialize in at least one weapon skill and gear up for it you're almost guaranteed to roll through most of what the game has to offer. The other choice you can make at this point is to hire a team before each mission. The concept is great but in practice you are disincentivized from doing it since it represents a money drain with no lasting benefit beyond making the combat even easier. I invested into drone control for a permanent companion instead and the money saved on mediocre pawns definitely paid off in the end.

The combat itself is…not very interesting. Regardless of your character, enemies are braindead and their tactics are very limited, making most of them fall to simple tactics such as backing up to trap them, or taking pot shots and going out of sight. Near the end of the game, vents allow drones to freely kill all enemies and duck into them, trivializing those encounters. There are a few battles where gimmicks are introduced however they came across more as tedium than engaging sadly. Even worse, some sections during missions have no enemies yet you are still locked into combat movement, meaning you need to agonizingly slowly move your characters forward one by one. 

Although everything is technically functional, most elements come with some degree of clunkiness to them, part of which could be due to the age of the game but it does not do it many favours. On top of those limitations, myself and many others have experienced softlocks that required reloading so keep a series of saves ready between missions.

[h1]Completion[/h1]
Seeing as the game has no achievements, there's nothing much to say here. Content-wise the game is entirely linear and the few sidequests aren't really missable and only tend to reward more experience or cash so you're likely to see most of it fairly quickly. My hours are inflated due to idling with the game on but it's definitely not a very long experience.

Ill be honest, theres a lot of good in this game.  I liked the story and the RPG elements were fairly solid.  But...lets get on why i cant recommend this game, even if its free...yes, save yourself the frustration.

THIS GAME DOES NOT UNDERSTAND HOW % WORKS!!

and its so fucking irritating that i literally had to stop playing.  If I average a hit % of 86, how do i miss 75% of my attacks?  How do I miss 50% of my 99% success attacks?  its ridiculous.  The worst part is when you get into the final stages of the game.  You fight these giant bugs that, once killed, turn into spirit bugs.  in order to kill them you have to hit them with a special gun that does 15 damage.  only you and one other person have this gun and the gun has only 2 rounds...so typically its shoot twice, reload for your round.  You can miss one shot and per round and still kill  the spirit bug.  if you dont kill it then it forms back into a physical bug and you have to kill it again...repeat this process...

i finally turned the game off when, while have an 86% chance to hit with both characters, i was missing 2 shots per round.  so, kill the physical bug, shoot the spirit bug twice, miss twice and repeat the process again and again all the while the bugs are whittling down your character and your NPCs.  its fucking stupid and it took me out of the game.  im not sure how you hit 50% of the time with an 86% chance to hit - and this is a theme throughout the game, but you really notice it with these bugs because its so vital you hit them twice while in spirit mode.  so fucking frustrating.  i thought id finish the game then this bullshit happened.  im done.

I thought this would be a good place to start playing a bunch of recent CRPGs because I remember it was a pretty successful Kickstarter and sorta responsible for the resurgence in interest to the genre. THAT was a bad decision. It came out in 2013 I think and yet feels worse to play than Baldur's Gate 1. Literally just clicking around the map and trying to interact with stuff was such a chore, half the time when you click someone to talk to your character just turns to them and the dialogue box doesn't even open. Then in combat the UI is atrocious where entire classes are devoted to using spells but all of your spells are in a drop down menu with no ability to hotkey them, requiring so many clicks just to cast a spell that could've been bound to Q and done on a hover-over mouse target. 

The story was shockingly simple for having the possibility of sci-fi and fantasy to draw from. It's also shockingly linear. I thought a defining point of this genre was being able to tackle problems from multiple angles, but almost every mission has exactly 1 solution, you gotta talk to this one guy and get a thing to put next to the thing and sneak in, no you can't talk your way in, no you can't brute force your way in. I feel terrible for anyone who wanted to engage with the game's one sorta unique feature, hacking, because there are literally like 4 places in the entire game where it can be used whatsoever, and only if your main character is the hacker because a hacker party member is, for some reason, unable to be used unless you're in combat. Not that they're any fun to do because they play the exact same as combat, just spam clicking on enemies as you shoot whatever your default weapon is, occasionally clicking through 3 drop down menus to cast a buff spell if you feel like it. By the time you finally have a party, which is like half-way through the game, you end up just forgetting about cover and spells and drones and all that shit and just hire a ton of dudes with shotguns to blast apart anything that walks your way. No point in having a balanced party for skill checks because only your main character is allowed to interact with objects, so why not just spam AoE infinite ammo no cooldown guns? 

I got about 75% of the way through the game and was just trying to get through the arduous combats as fast as I could until I encountered a bug where I became unable to pass my turn or take any actions during the final encounter of a huge area, and the game has NO quick save feature (or rebindable keys for that matter holy shit) so when I reloaded I had to do the entire mission again. Fuckin abysmal, I threw in the towel. Story, characters, setting, controls, combat, RPG, everything a waste of time. 1/10.
