112632526.review:
Ultimately I enjoyed my playthrough of Shadowrun Returns, but unfortunately I can't recommend it to other players for the simple reason that it contains a couple of major, game-breaking bugs which nearly prevented me from advancing through the campaign to completion. Certain events on a couple of specific missions would repeatedly fail to trigger, effectively soft-locking the game and forcing me to reload prior saves or even restart entire levels from the beginning in the hope of magically avoiding whatever caused the failure to occur on the previous attempt. These problems were admittedly very few and far between, but when they did crop up they were absolutely impossible to ignore.

     The fact that these issues exist (with no reliable, easily implemented workaround or troubleshooting available either on the game's Steam forums or anywhere else on the web) in a 'finished' game is unacceptable. And since this is now a bit of an older game and development on it has completely stopped, there is no prospect of these problems ever being resolved. It seems unfair that the developers are still able to sell this game in its current state without at least providing some kind of disclaimer on the store page to warn potential buyers before purchase.

     It's a shame, because if it weren't for the glaring issues outlined above, Shadowrun Returns would easily get a thumbs up instead. The game's graphics are not bad for its age, character creation is varied and interesting, the plot is compelling enough to keep you invested in what's happening, the campaign is reasonably long, etc. But it's just not worth the frustration or wasted time of having to deal with those bugs in order to get at the good parts when there are so many other great RPGs to choose from on Steam that have all the same selling points AND run smoothly. 

     If you're already a big fan of the Shadowrun series and/or you got the game in a bundle then by all means give it a try, but don't say that nobody warned you. For the average player looking to buy a decent top-down, turn-based RPG to play in their spare time, I'd say keep looking.

Shadowrun Returns has a solid gameplay and a deep narrative side with an above average story compared to other games. However, it's the less good Shadowrun game out of the three available on Steam. This makes sense, as Returns is the first game, and even if old doesn't always mean worse, it does in this case.

The story is far shorter than Hong Kong and Dragonfall, and I fell it's less interesting and transcendental than the other games. The characters present almost no development, and the long conversations filled with lore from the other Shadowrun games become direct and straight to the point dialogues. 

By any means Shadowrun Returns is a bad game, and I'm sure anyone who enjoyed other Shadowrun games will enjoy this one. But if someone is thinking about play the saga for the first time, I strongly recommend either Hong Kong or Dragonfall, as they are more complete and overall, more interesting.

I never got into the Shadowrun franchise, its tabletop stuff, nor the old Shadowrun game that came out on the NES, but when I saw this in the Steam store, I figured I would give it a go. Turns out, buying Shadowrun Returns was a good choice, because this Tactical RPG game is actually quite good to play.

The combat sections are really good and I like the character classes and stuff you can get, not to mention the whole setting of the Shadowrun brand. The story is alright, and it has some nice characters to meet; the portrait artwork for them are very well done. The matrix stages in the story is also a really cool environment to enter and fight in - particularly its combat mechanics.

My only drawbacks with Shadowrun Returns is the lack of companion characters to really bond with like most other RPG titles, the lack of achievements, and the rather linear layout of the game with little to do on the side between main story stages. Otherwise, a nice decent title to play through.

2. I was kinda curious about it as it kept on popping up when I was checking out other titles 
3. It was on sale for £2.74

Shadowrun Returns is an incredibly short and easy game. My run time doesn't give an accurate idea of it's length as it was left on idle for a duration multiple different times. It can definitely be completed in or under 10 hours.

[h1]THE VIBE[/h1]

Shadowrun Returns can easily be understood if you think of it as the love child between Blade Runner and Dungeons & Dragons.

In the not so distant future, magic has come back to our technologically advanced dystopian world. The game drips attitude and personality, so much so the song It Can't Rain All the Time from the movie The Crow can feel perfectly at home here. The game also provides plenty of that Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines vibe in regards to tone and general world building.

[h1]STORY SET UP[/h1]

You are a Shadowrunner, an individual who runs jobs outside of the black and white lines of the law for anyone willing to pay. The story greatly revolves around a Deadmans Switch which can be thought of as a last will and testimony sent to - in this case - an individual automatically when they die.

When your old Shadowrunner buddy Sam dies, you receive his Deadmans Switch asking for his killer to be caught for a handsome reward.

[h1]DIFFICULTY[/h1]

I played the entire game on the hardest difficulty and found this ridiculously easy the vast majority of times. When it wasn't ridiculously easy it was very easy. In short, this game provides zero challenge. 

[h1]CHARACTER CREATION[/h1]

LOVED IT! This game does something that most RPG, CRPG etc etc etc games does not..... it allows you to create a character that actually looks like the profile picture..... mind blown! All jokes aside, you can actually make a character that looks like the provided profile images. On that basis alone, I love it.

You get to select the obvious stuff such as gender and race. The races are human, elf, dwarf, orc and troll. Each race as you may expect provides a stat buff or increase if you prefer.

The stats in Shadowrun Returns follow a very simplistic logic. Example, if you want to increase your health points, you put points in your Body. Level one Body costs 1 Karma point aka upgrade point. Level two costs 2 Karma points etc. The rest of the categories have some sub categories such as Spellcasting is under Willpower. In other words, the more proficient you want to be in something, the more it's gonna cost you (upgrade point wise).

[h1]GENERAL GAMEPLAY STUFF[/h1]

Shadowrun Returns is a very short and linear game that really provides as a good opener for the Shadowrun series. Combat is like the plot, very short and linear with little to no thinking needed. In some respects the game is almost like an interactive book. Only two fights at the very end change the formula a little bit.

[h1]LIKES[/h1]

* The world is genuinely cool
* I liked the fact you are the main character only, there's no companions per se
* Character models look like the profile images

[h1]DISLIKES[/h1]

* Feels like a really polished section of or DLC to a 'main game'
* It was confusing how the inventory works. Swapping and buying items is easy but at the start of the game, you have no indication of how it is done or where your loot or inventory actually is. It isn't explained either from what I can remember. You just kinda stumble across it it at the relevant point and then it all clicks together, haphazardly.

This is a great game. The story was engaging, and straightforward. So many modern stories have double-cross, triple-cross, and so on. So many times they follow such cliches as denigrating the player as just a pawn in this wider story, or just twists the plot for the sake of it. Here was little of that, and I liked the fact that the friends you make remain friends and are not discovered to be working for the bad guys.

The game play worked well and there was enough information provided to understand how to do most everything. There are plenty of things I didn't even try, like overwatch for example, so I guess there's more to do if I attempt a second play through. The graphics are nice, and the audio works well.

109829468.review:
I adore Shadowrun: Dragonfall, and Shadowrun: Hong Kong is one of my favorite games of all time. Naturally, I was excited to play the game that started the franchise: Shadowrun Returns: Dead Man's Switch. Once I began playing, however, my excitement was quickly replaced with frustration. I was fully prepared for a significantly less refined user interface, and the loss of many quality of life features. What I wasn't prepared for was the drop in writing quality.

When compared to the stellar writing in both of its sequels, Shadowrun Returns suffers quite heavily. Where Dragonfall and Hong Kong do an excellent job of crafting diverse narratives in which characters' cultural backgrounds are centered, Returns falls back on countless tired and cringeworthy stereotypes. Where Dragonfall tells the story of the members of a found family dealing with grief and loss, Returns deprives you of party members, and has you go it alone for most of the game. Where Hong Kong tells excellent disability narratives through Gaichu and Ambrose, Returns [spoiler]removes the arm of a main character, replaces it with an identical prosthetic, then moves on with barely a second thought[/spoiler]. Even the sentence-level writing suffers: I lost count of the number of times a new character was introduced with the exact same language, with nothing but a few adjectives and metaphors swapped around. It got exhausting very quickly.

As much as it pains me to say it, if you've never played a Shadowrun game before, I highly recommend starting with Dragonfall or Hong Kong. All of the stories are self-contained, and you will almost certainly have a better experience. Plus, they're a pair of STELLAR games. If you have played Shadowrun and Hong Kong and want more of the same, this is probably not the best place to look for it.

107694520.review:
Muy buen juego para los fans de los videojuegos de Rol por turnos. Posee una herramienta de personalización de avatares que permite definir muchos rasgos del personaje (sexo, clase, apariencia y atributos) que influirán mucho en el modo campaña que viene incluido por defecto con el juego. Respecto a la historia, hay que advertir que se toma su tiempo en ser develada (se hace a "cuentagotas", como si estuvieses viendo una película de suspenso y terror), por lo que recomiendo este juego solo a aquellas personajes que les gusta LEER y son amantes de la literatura.

El ambiente en el que se desarrolla el videojuego es totalmente GRIS, es decir, en varios puntos de la historia, tendrás que tomar decisiones duras que impactan el devenir de la historia, y en otros casos, las consecuencias de haber tomado una mala decisión, pueden simplemente hacerte perder a un personaje importante ó desaprovechar una recompensa que ya estaba al alcance de la mano; Pero es en este punto, de la narrativa, el mundo gris y sus duras decisiones, donde Shadowrun Returns es GRANDE.!!

El juego posee buenos gráficos para su época, y en el audio y música, necesita el apoyo de pistas mas variadas, ya que se vuelven repetitivas de tanto escucharlas. Su gameplay es bueno también, aunque en este apartado el juego trata de ofrecer rejugabilidad a través de la elección inicial de distintos niveles de dificultad, pero esto solo lo logra motivando al jugador a crear partidas nuevas para elegir un nuevo avatar de una nueva clase, obligando a jugar la campaña desde el principio.

En una escala del 1 al 10, le daría un 8...por el detalle de la falta mas pistas de audio, y de que a día de hoy, no existen nuevas campañas descargables en idioma español para este juego.

Most of the options seem to boil down to range, melee, pet. 

The game isn't overly difficult (thanks to a save feature that didn't exist at launch) the story for a cheap game is good. The art style is decent and the world is interesting. The biggest shame is that it didn't give a nice large world to play in.

To be completely transparent: I have a soft spot for Shadowrun. I Kickstarted this game. I play the tabletop games. I've loved Shadowrun ever since I was a kid in 4th grade staring confusedly at my TV with the SR Genesis game running. Magic and VR? Trolls and machine guns? I was the exact target audience.

While some people were a little hit or miss on this title, I loved every second of it. The combat is tense, challenging and rewarding. The story is intriguing and packed with references for fans of the old Genesis and SNES games - and the world just oozes with the tongue-in-cheek, grimey, chromed-up feel that only Shadowrun delivers.

Full disclosure: I do think this is the weakest title out of the trilogy, but not by much - anyone going backwards will miss a few quality of life changes in the mechanics and class abilities, but otherwise it's a great game.

106641548.review:
Remember back before 3D, when there was an entire generation of isometric RPGs with D20 rules and deep story?  You can still buy them, but within five minutes you throw them at the wall because they are so [b]ugly[/b] and [b]painful[/b] to play.
This is the same style of game, except [b]not ugly[/b] and [b]not painful[/b].
(Also not sword-and-sorcery fantasy, which I'm utterly sick of.)

It's tough to say whether I prefer Wasteland 2 & 3 or Shadowrun Returns / Dragonfall / Hong Kong.
They're all great.  Shadowrun feels a bit more indie.

This is the first game in the trilogy, and there's a few quality-of-life features missing that were added in later games.  In particular, the UI feels phone-first in a couple of places, where keyboard bindings would just make sense.

The worldbuilding and artwork is all solid.
The combat is not new, but it's a solid formula that's implemented well.
You can't do a purely non-combatant run, but there are plenty of places where dialogue choices give substantial advantages.  On the downside, this means if you tend to click through dialogue without reading it, you can occasionally shoot yourself in the foot :-)

PS: in the workshop there's some homebrew efforts to port the SNES campaign to this engine, but last time I looked, they weren't yet better than replaying the original.  Doing that professionally as a paid DLC would be pretty cool...

105947844.review:
7.5/10. Great, cyber-punk noire atmosphere, with a dash of fantasy. The mechanics felt like a marriage between the Shadowrun tabletop RPG (at least, 5th edition) and X-COM (only, you know, fair). I dug the unique way that you build-up your character's stats and abilities (though, I did not discover until the final area that you can activate unlocked weapon abilities by clicking on the ammunition. It does say that in the tutorial, so that is entirely on me). It makes good use of buffs, debuffs and cool-downs. There are plenty of intriguing characters (some of which you can recruit to go on missions) and solid dialogue. I loved the callbacks to the SNES cult classic "Shadowrun", 

It loses a few points for a couple of bugs that I encountered, which I guess are pretty common. They are back to back bugs, but the Steam forum should be able to help you out if you encounter them. While the art style and character portraits are good, my 3D avatar never looked great.  I went for a decking build, which is pretty fun, but I was disappointed that none of the cyber-enhancement options ever felt like they were worth getting.  Even though the ending of the main story-line was satisfying, I didn't feel like there were enough side-missions or enemy variety for such a diverse world (there is a map editor and fan-made modules for download, though I don't know how they are). I'm not saying that I feel cheated by lack of content, just that I wanted more of a good thing.  

I will probably play the two sequels to this game before I come back and try playing as a shaman or something. But it was really enjoyable, and thanks to the people who made it!

105773213.review:
Shadowrun Returns: Dead man's switch may have some minor flaws, but it's a great experience for narrative-driven RPG fans and an excellent one for table-top Shadowrun players. [b]I'd buy it at full price if I had a job, but you can get it at generous discounts for as little as 3-4$ since it was released almost a decade ago.[/b] One more thing before diving into the review: this is the first part of the Shadowrun trilogy, and if you just want to experience Shadowrun glory for a single gameplay, head straight to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/300550/Shadowrun_Dragonfall__Directors_Cut/] Shadowrun: Dragonfall[/url], which outshines Dead man's switch in all aspects.

Shadowrun is a renowned table-top system introduced in 1989, which is alive and well, introducing the sixth edition in 2019. It mixes fantasy features with cyberpunk efficiently and entertainingly. Racism is alive and well since Humans hate Orcs, Elves are arrogant towards Humans, Everyone despises Trolls, and Dragons are mighty capitalist overlords conspiring to rule all the races. Furthermore, there's tons of hacking, The Matrix is worse than Neo could've imagined, and people with salary jobs are simply called "wage-slaves". It's the near future, so to speak.

After releasing games for SNES in the early 90's, and an FPS for Windows and Xbox in 2007, Shadowrun took a break and was revived via Kickstarter by Harebrained Schemes, which is now owned by Paradox Interactive. Kickstarter was a massive success, raising 1.8 million dollars, way above the required 400k. And here are the results of this generous funding.

[b]This game is beautiful.[/b] The graphics pass the test of time, with a classic isometric view, a well-done cyberpunk architecture/atmosphere, and a wonderful, although slightly repetitive, soundtrack. It's a narrative-driven experience with a light combat system, which may be disappointing for combat lovers, but is welcomed by those seeking a good story. I loved this mix, just as much as I love Jack & Coke. 

You'll dive into a neo-noir kind of detective story-line that's immersive and gives all the motivation you need to push forwards. You actually care about NPCs (although Dragonfall is way ahead at that), intuitive dialogues, and a spoonful of humor appropriate for a dystopian setting. A minor spoiler ahead: [spoiler]plot twist and the second part of the story might seem out of context, but those are the actual events that happened in Seattle 2054, as written in the New Seattle table-top book. However, I found this narrative twist unnecessary and would've continued the crime investigation line.[/spoiler]

[b]The replay value is minimal[/b], and even though there are different ways to complete quests, it doesn't matter too much at the end. This game is best experienced as a linear immersive story-line, which will leave you wanting more. [i]Luckily, more is what you'll get since they released Shadowrun: Dragonfall and Shadowrun: Hong Kong in two years, one after another.[/i]

Dead man's switch could be better. The Matrix and combat systems, items, replayability. But it doesn't spoil the game; it just means it's a first attempt at successfully introducing Shadowrun as an isometric RPG. And for those that want a smoother experience, head straight to Dragonfall for a story in anarchist Berlin that will stick with you for a while.

I have changed. About seven years ago, when this game was released, I wasn't interested in it because it was turn-based (which takes away a lot of action that was present in the SNES version of Shadowrun). The appeal that action-based games that train players to have quick reflexes works better on young people, which I'm no longer part of.

I now see that the decision to make Shadowrun as a turn-based game was the correct one, maybe even the best one. It enables the player to experience the story (which is something that becomes secondary when the action is the most attractive feature of a game, such as Megaman X, which does have a plot but almost no one knows it because everyone plays it for the actions). The story is interesting, but it has too much fantasy for my taste. If the Shadowrun franchise were to grow more realistic, it could make good games that are suited to the growing mood of the world (the slow dissolution of nation-states and the rise of global corporations).

I think this game is good, well done. Not spetacular, but not bad either.

101786728.review:
A short, sweet, and simple turn-based RPG that keeps a good story going until its bitter end. The ending does feel like a cop out, but I'm told that later iterations of the franchise make up for it in terms of refined mechanics and sheer story duration. Shadowrun: Returns instils the belief that it very well could, and I'm tempted to buy out the franchise. 

As someone who doesn't really go for the RPG genre, the game does a great job stringing the player along by providing you with heaps of resources to use as you go along. Not necessarily items, but money and upgrade points (Karma). As a habitual resource hoarder that played on normal, I was disappointed when I finished the game with a boatload of coin and level up points. I expected the game to be a bit longer, so I held on to a sizeable amount of both for at least a quarter of the game. Don't do that - it made me feel as if I held myself back from enjoying the game as it was meant to be played. The game actively punishes resource hoarders. 

Go all in on skills that seem interesting to you, as it feels like there's just too much choice and too few levels to make the most out of their diverse skill trees. Because the game offers so many unique ways to go through it, I do have this strange itch to re-specialize my character and run through the game with a better understanding of the game's unique mechanics - hacking, spells, and synergy between different character specialities all seem incredibly convoluted as you go throughout the game. By the time you think you have a handle on it, the game ends abruptly. 

I just feel slighted by the game's duration. It offers a highly intricate skill tree and breadth of spells, weapons, and other modifications. But, you could easily beat this game in 8-10 hours on an average difficulty. I do wish this game dabbled in more sidequests to avoid the feeling of not feeling like any of the choices you pick matter - you're just playing this game with too many options on too little time. Is it a life metaphor? Who knows.

I do know that it was a very pleasant way to re-introduce myself into the world of turn-based RPGs, but it has ignited a hunger for a more wholesome experience this just didn't fully sate.

100078288.review:
This is a decent cRPG based on the Shadowrun tabletop game.  While I never played the tabletop I always thought the lore was rather interesting and I enjoyed the SNES game I finished long ago.  

As far as gameplay goes, the combat is similar to XCOM with its overwatch and cover systems.  I love the XCOM games, so I enjoyed the combat in Shadowrun Returns.

My playthrough involved a Troll Physical Adept who used unarmed combat, which is considered to be the weakest archetype in this game.  Even with a less than optimal character choice I didn't have too much trouble beating the game.  In fact, I utterly wrecked the final boss, though the level before that was more difficult due to the crits I took from powerful ranged damage. I also didn't have to spend a lot on equipment, so I ended up with tons of money for hiring runners. 

The RPG aspects are decent but not as complex as other cRPGs I've played.  It seemed more combat focused and there weren't a lot of points of interest to explore, so if you're looking for a cRPG that focuses more on obtaining knowledge and talking your way out of things, Planescape: Torment is a better choice.  If I decide to play this again, I'd probably go with a Decker since that opens up a lot of additional rewards and it seems to fit the theme better.  

The story is a straightforward and linear murder mystery, but it gets creepy at times, so I enjoyed it.  It explores a lot of the things that make cyberpunk games enjoyable such as meatpuppets, corporate scheming and battles in cyberspace.  The one complaint I have is that the player character isn't affected by the game's plot so if you're looking for character growth this isn't a good game for that.  

I haven't played Dragonfall or Hong Kong yet and they seem more developed than this first entry in the series, but Shadowrun Returns was a fun experience overall.

100027679.review:
While I loved playing this game for the 16 hours I did, there is an enormous and 100% game breaking bug in it.  

When you get to a certain point in the game (after a LOT of character advancement and skill development) you need to enter a building to kick off a chapter.  Well....IF you happen to have a Drone equipped (and a drone is a REALLY useful thing to have), once you get into the building, you lose all control of your character and they have reverted to what appears to be a test character.  You lost all items, you lose all stats, and most importantly....you CAN'T CONTROL YOUR CHARACTER.  All you can do is watch while you run around the room until you hit a dark area and then...nothing.

At this point the game is completely unplayable because you have no control over your character.  All you can do apparently is reload to a previous save, drop the drone, then go to the building.  Then reload the save with the drone, and try again.  Maybe the game will work, but probably not.  I've seen someone say they got it to work after trying 'dozens and dozens of times'.
  
This sort of game breaking bug is unacceptable.  There is no way this should have passed QA/QC.  Honestly I refuse to believe it even went to any sort of competent QA.
  
Save yourself from wasting a lot of time getting into a cool story and an otherwise decent game.

99458724.review:
First Shadowrun game (and I had no idea its origins were so old).
At first glance, what makes Shadowrun stand out from other cyberpunk worlds is the prominent fantasy element. In return, you get no sentient androids and the topic of transhumanism is kind of taken for granted and never touched upon. 
And while I'm not too fond of fantasy [except for Conan-like grimness], I think it fits very well here and it's surely a breath of fresh air that gives Shadowrun a personality of its own.

Now... the first thing you'll notice is that the writing is damn GREAT. It really sets the tone: the characters speak in a variety of slangs according to their identity, there are plenty of environmental descriptions that may as well fit in cyberpunk novels, and so on.
Overall, the atmosphere is top-notch and the seedy, corrupt and poverty-ridden urban sprawl we love so much in cyberpunk media is definitely there 100%. As someone else already said, it's 'true cyberpunk'.

I felt the start to be too fast, tho. You get thrown into the story with no introduction at all. It all happens quick and basically assumes you're familiar with Shadowrun already.
Plus, the gameplay mechanics REEEEALLY take their time to show up, so the first hours just feel like a very well-written novel accompanied with an hyper-basic combat system.
(The ending is great, although I wouldn't have minded one final stop by the Union. So that's a bit rushed too.)

But give it time.
The first hours may feel like an eternal introduction, but after that it'll be a pleasurable ride!
The skill tree may seem irrelevant at first, but it will really make a difference later on.
The combat system gets more and more satisfying the more you play and advance with your character, also thanks to bigger fire power that is accompanied with gratifyingly fat gun sounds. And btw, the soundtrack is also really good and gives off that cyberpunk vibe quite well.

The story is very intriguing and the characters very interesting folks (the companions too)!
So yeah, I really enjoyed my journey to get justice for Sam, and every new detail I discovered felt like an exciting twist to the plot.

Plot and awesome dialogues will keep you hooked, but don't expect an open-world game: there's a hub you always get back to, but it's a linear trip through predetermined areas.
In fact, there are plenty of stakes to attest the woodiness felt at the beginning... You'll get used to it, but all the limitations are still downside.
Indeed, the linear progression, the almost non-existent environmental interaction, the impossibility to kill anyone that isn't an enemy, etc. make you feel very routed into a specific direction.
Besides, the talk options (even tho always top-notch, quality-wise) are often different ways of saying the same thing, and I felt like the choices that actually mattered were very few... most often it's just a matter of taking the secondary quest or not.
There's still some space to 'do your own thing' through the character's skill tree, which is fun to build, but I think it's fair to say that Shadowrun Returns doesn't let many doors open for experimentation and sandbox elements. Or, actually, it never does.
On this, I've gotta say that it's the polar opposite of Deus Ex.

That depends on what you're looking for, as for considering it a good or a bad thing.
Personally, I'm obsessed (not pleasure, just compulsion) with seeing every single pixel of any game I play, so I often end up abandoning free-roaming games because they're a bit too much to handle for me.
Had it been more open, instead of linear and strict as it is, I might haven't enjoyed it as much.

I beat it in 20 hrs across 4 straight days and all the cons ceased to matter as soon as I got deeper into the plot.
I mean, it's really addictive if you let it be. It's exactly what I needed right now and I think it's really immersive and fun to play.
Before this I played 2 short games and before that I've had a 3 years long phase of disregard for singleplayer games and hadn't played anything at all in a year.
The amount of hours I spent daily on this, considering what I just said, speaks for itself.

99456313.review:
I mainly played this on GOG, so my hours on Steam do not accurately reflect my experience.

As a cRPG, its decent. It's respectful of your time, which seems to be a trademark of all of Harebrained Schemes forays into the world of Shadowrun. The combat is decent, and it feels like there's is a healthy pool of options to choose from when it comes to tactics.

Despite this, it's really not necessary to play this. The sequels Dragonfall and Hong Kong expand upon the formula this set out to the point where this just feels like a tech demo meant to test the waters for demand. In addition, there is no overarching narrative between all the games, so you won't miss out on any important plot details if you do.

It may seem bizarre to not recommend a good game, but as previously stated, you really don't need to play this. At all.

As with many of my reviews I wish it was not a binary choice, likely I'd pick an average score here.

The game had potential, I liked the world, the characters, etc. but some things made the whole experience painful and it became a drag to play the game.

Why are we almost always in combat mode in dungeons? It makes it so painfully slow to move, and with absolutely no benefit whatsoever... Animations are also pretty slow, I found no way to accelerate them but maybe it's possible with the console. The music wants to make you feel you're in danger, but it's so forced and it's the repetitive tones over and over and over again...

The combat did not feel particularly interesting either, shoot, miss, shoot, heal, shoot, done. Not much to think about, maybe apart from the last fight when there's an order to things... Yeah the characters have skills, especially the mage, but since I didn't play that I didn't have to care too much.

I played the game both on straight GNU/Linux and on a Chromebook with Crostini without issue.

97883723.review: This RPG deserves more attention than it gets. Not only that this game might be the title responsible for the comeback of classic isometric CRPGs, but also compared to many other CRPG titles of this new era it doesn't feel under-cooked, nor directionless. It's one of the few modern CRPGs with a good combat system in my humble opinion. I might be biased, but I do prefer this kind of tactical turn-based combat to the so called "real time with pause" combat, which is trying to be both tactical and action-like at the same time, while it fails at both. I don't hate on "real time with pause" RPGs, but the turn-based combat system is simply the superior choice for me. So in this regard I think that the authors made the right decision when they introduced this well designed turn-based combat system. If you are anything like me, you are going to love it. The karma system confused me a little at the start, but when I got into it, I found out that it's actually very well thought-out and functional system, which is easily understandable. I know that some people have criticized it for its simplicity, but personally I don't see a reason to make it more complex. That would feel forced and unnecessary to me. The game is little bit more linear compared to most RPGs, but I must say that I was glad for that fact since it gave the story much more natural flow. The missions are quite varied and especially the undercover missions are great for breaking up the pace. This could have been my favorite RPG of the decade if only I was more interested in the world (I guess fantasy-cyberpunk is not my cup of tea) and the "Into the Depths" mission didn't get on my nerves so much.

* Combat is Ok, but the current state reminds me of Fallout's without the gore.
* Character customization is there, but then it feels limited too.
* Story is linear without exploration which kinda sucks (compared to SNES and Megadrive ones).
* Shaman with one handed pistol expertise and haste is a joke as I can kill 2 or 3 characters before they have a chance.

95767754.review:
[b]Playing status:[/b] finished the game

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Shadowrun Returns[/b] is a story-heavy turn-based strategy game in a world where cyberpunk and fantasy blend together. The game was originally released as a [url=http://www.shadowruntabletop.com/]tabletop[/url] game and also a part of a [url=https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/532/Shadowrun_Trilogy/]trilogy[/url], with this game being the first. As someone who never played the original tabletop game, this will be my first time stepping into this series.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 4 difficulties
- Limited resources
- Freedom to build the character that you want

[b]Cons:[/b]
- No skill reset
- Some puzzles don't give enough hints to solve them manually

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you like turn-based strategy games that are heavily focused on the story, buy this game.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
The visuals in [b]Shadowrun Returns[/b] are not that different from the environment that we see today, filled with hi-tech technologies to make it fits the cyberpunk-themed world. Despite it combining both cyberpunk and fantasy themes, I didn't find any trace of fantasy from the visuals. The environment still looks good as long as you are not looking at the character models closely, although the top-down view helps a lot. Character portraits are also good enough to please you with their gorgeous look, even for the ugliest man that the game claims to be.

[h3]Story[/h3]
You need to read a lot to understand the story, and by that, I mean a lot. The game does a good job to convey what a mere portrait couldn't do by explaining everything that a character looks like or do, which helps to see their personalities. The inner monologue that you have when you are moving between places also helps to resonate with what's going on in the main character's mind.

The use of exquisite words might make the story to be hard to read to some people. I had difficulties understanding some words and there were times when I had to reread the same dialogues over and over. Luckily, the game does a good job of doing a recap of the current situation, which helps a lot to confirm my assumption and inform me of the info that I missed.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2547533564

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
I didn't expect that the gameplay will be this detailed and varied, giving you more options on what you can do in combat. Characters are divided into several races that have different traits. From there, you can build the character to be what you want - you can wield guns, hack computers, shoots magic, operates drones, summons spirits, or do a combination of them. You'll also have stat points that you can allocate to accommodate these skills, and if it's not enough, you also can buy gears to increase your stat. Everything is customizable to allow you to create the character that you need.

For a game that allows you to customize a lot of things, I found it hard to believe that it also limits your freedom by providing limited resources. It was hard to decide my character's build since you only have limited stat points with no option to reset them. Moreover, you also have a limited amount of money to buy gears and possibly consumables, and there are just too many options to choose from. In the end, I chose to build a character that didn't need much tinkering. It did work after some adjustment, although I wished I could reset some of my stat points after realizing that I invested in a stat that I never used.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2547533758

The game is mostly linear, with you having to talk to characters to progress the game. You'll be able to select between several options to progress the story which will lead to a conversation between you and other people. Despite the many dialogue options, everything will eventually lead to the same conclusion, with you having to deal with different dialogues. There are some exceptions, although they usually don't matter for the story as a whole. Your stat will also help to skip through some parts of the game if you have the right stat to back it up.

[b]Combat[/b]
Combat is the same as other turn-based strategy games, with you having up to four characters in your party. Although you'll start solo, the game will allow you to hire more party members for one mission later on. All combats are scripted, meaning that you won't deal with it unless you need it to progress the story. There will be times when you have to deal with more than battles in the same area, and you need to conserve HP between battles.

The addition of [i]deckers[/i] helps to make the combat more colorful. You can think of [i]deckers[/i] as a more improved version of hackers, where you can project yourself in cyberspace. They will be able to do this while you're in combat, allowing you to do two types of combats at the same time. Since [i]deckers[/i] will be alone in cyberspace, they will be able to summon some programs to help them, provided that they have the summon programs equipped. This will make them weaker in real-world battles since their equipment slot will be filled with [i]decker[/i]-related items. The non-[i]deckers[/i] will also need to protect the [i]deckers[/i] while they are connected to cyberspace since they will have their hands full with virtual battles. Sadly, there aren't many areas where you can do these things. I wish the game will also explore more into this side.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2547533500

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the campaign in 12.5h in the easiest difficulty. There are four difficulties in total, and since I'm not good at strategy games, I found the difficulty to fit me well. There were times when my party members died since I wasn't being careful, but you won't have trouble in defeating the enemies as long as you're careful. You don't have to worry much about your build either - I admit that I spent a lot of my stats on a stat that I never used, but I still able to do fine in battles.

[b]Problems[/b]
Some puzzles don't give enough hints to solve manually, forcing me to brute force the solution if I didn't have the right stat to bypass them. The accuracy for some characters is also messed up - I could get a very low accuracy even when I am standing right in front of an enemy.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I prefer to call [b]Shadowrun Returns[/b] a visual novel with a turn-based strategy element rather than a turn-based strategy game due to its number of dialogues. I didn't mean it as a bad thing though - the narrative does a good job to let you immersed with the world, although people who hate reading will find the number of dialogues to be daunting to read. Moreover, there are a lot of subtle details that you need to figure out which can be easily missed if you just glimpsed through the texts.

Surprisingly, they also didn't slack off on the gameplay department. I was surprised to see how well-thought it is, with the various builds that you can try out and use. Although I couldn't try all builds because of the resource limitation, I could try some of them by hiring people that use that build. Sadly, there wasn't a lot of combat in this game, or maybe it's overshadowed by the numerous amount of dialogues. It's still an enjoyable game though, and if you like to play a game in such settings, this is your game. Just make sure to read the dialogues as you play - you'll miss a lot otherwise.

94272044.review:
[h1] The Good Part [/h1]

The story is very good but a little bit short. It can be serious and funny when it matters. Some NPCs have sidequests that can be completed with more than one outcome and that also reveals a bit more about their character.
Character customization is good when it comes to skills and abilities.

[h1] What Could Be Better? [/h1]

The controls are a bit clunky at times, specially during combat, where I have experienced some irresponsive commands, but nothing game-breaking. I also feel that the cover mechanics could use some more work to have them more in sync with the terrain, e.g., right now opening a door while being against the wall doesn't provide cover. I'd also like more outfit options for your character, since you can use only 2-3 different outfits (if you care about choosing an outfit that matches with skills).

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

The game has some minor problems with combat that didn't impact very much my enjoyment of the game. The story and world-building is good and got me interested in the setting.

93475106.review:
I'm recommending this solely for the atmosphere. If you enjoy the Shadowrun or Cyberpunk type aesthetic and turn based games then you'll probably enjoy this. If you don't look elsewhere.

There are two main components to the game. A very linear story-driven narrative, and turn based strategic combat. The problem is that neither are especially good. The story goes from kind of interesting to... weird. It's certainly not cliche at least. And the combat, even on max difficulty, is just trivial - so it makes it quite boring.

But negatives aside, the atmosphere and aesthetic are engaging and well done. So if you're longing for that Shadowrun fix, this game can probably help scratch that itch a bit.

93024481.review:
A fairly simple, linear game that progresses in a level by level fashion with minimal options for exploration, Shadowrun Returns is still entertaining. For the most part, you just follow a yellow quest indicator from one objective to the next, performing tactical combat on missions and clicking through a series of preset dialog options to advance the quest between levels. It's not exactly the most immersive or expansive gameplay on the market, but the story and environment is the point here, and the mystery keeps it entertaining if you have enough patience to enjoy any game more complex than Call of Duty 47: Combat Reigniticated.

Really, I only bought this game because I played Shadowrun on the SNES as a kid, but it's a worthy successor and a nice respite from the endlessly open world games that send you aimlessly bouncing around quest and map markers for days on end. Think about a game like Skyrim or Fallout 4 where you wind up chaining yourself to one side quest after another and see this as the opposite of that mindset. Shadowrun Returns is more about crafting a singular story with a set of characters, and it does it well, even if that means there aren't a billion different ways you can wander away from the point of the game or an inventory system you can fill with every single broom you come across.

Shadowrun Returns is GOOD!

it is like playing a cyberpunk themed adventure with UFO enemy unknown styled turn base combat sections.
I love both so that was an instant hit with me.

Here a re the things i liked about Shadowrun Returns
[+] The whole game is relatively easy, it's just like playing a point and click adventure with turn based combat elements. You can play it without being on steam and as long as you enjoy the story.
[+] Wide selection of arsenal, either projectile or melee weaponry, some weapons are based on real world brands
[+] The sound track of the title/main menu screen is awesome, it comes in my mind and I find myself humming it quite often. Also the in game soundtracks remind me of Deus Ex Human Revolution.
[+] Combat is turn based a'la UFO enemy unkown, only more simplified and enjoyable nevertheless.
[+] It can be played at the players own pace.
[+] A decent variety on how you want to approach your gameplay: either be a gunslinger, magician or tech wizard, something that adds to the replayability.


A few cons here and there but nothing major and these are:
[-] Windows with descriptions on level items sometimes overlap each other.
[-] The cyber prosthetics should be more varied, also did not like the Essence cap.
[-] The main story is quite linear one way or another, sometimes there are different options of approaching something or someone.
[-] The graphics loook a bit dated, but I guess it is a novelty at this point

I would recommend that you try Shadowrun Returns, especially if you're a fan of the cyberpunk genre and you enjoy turn based strategy games.

92719621.review:
I bought this game on sale after reading some cool Shadowrun novels and wanted to play an RPG game in that setting.

I just played it in 2021 and I realize that this game is from 2013 - so it's quite old and I will consider the age in my review.

First things first: In general I cannot recommend this game and I will elaborate on my review. In my opinion this game is an option ONLY for hardcore Shadowrun fans AND if it is on a high discount.

Pro:
* Shadowrun :)
* Nice sound

Con:
* Graphics is really annoying: The isometric view sucks and you cannot change the camera position. For a turn-based game this is really bad when you move into a position just to find out that you cannot aim at your target. The turn may be lost and you even want to re-load.
* The game itself is way too linear. Basically there is no freedom - you follow the story. Period.
* Actually you can move in small - sometimes tiny - maps only. No way to explore anything outside the small/tiny maps.
* It's not immersive at all. I never had the feeling to really be there and feel "Shadowrun" if you know what I mean. Lack of ambience.
* A lot of text reading - no voice over. Maybe acceptable back in 2013.
* Fights are very repetitive and short.
* Basically the game alternates between you talking to people (read text, few dialog options) and then you fighting. Then repeat.

The game felt boring to me and at some point I just wanted to finish it. That's actually really sad because I've read some really great Shadowrun books and I think the setting has definitely great potential for a PC game. But this game did not pick up the atmosphere. Maybe due to the fact that the whole story basically unfolds via dialogs the story itself is quite short. I always had the feeling the game just scratches on the Shadowrun surface.

All in all I cannot recommend this game.

I got this close to release many years ago. Decided to give it another go after having gotten the trilogy of games for free on another platform. I made it nearly the whole way through the campaign and mostly had a good time. It's a bit more like an adventure game than most CRPGs I've played, but still pretty cool for the atmosphere. I did have one constant gripe throughout, though - the UI didn't seem to always engage my clicks where I wanted. It wasn't a big issue....until close to the final encounters.

My game just kept soft-locking after some scripted dialogue interrupts combat. And there were about 3 fights before this happened, where you are stuck in combat the whole time, and (genius decision here) you can't save in the middle of combat. Fallout, a game that came out over a decade before SRR, handled turn-based combat better. What. happened. here?! Worse yet, I found a forum post that stated in 2014 about this issue and was revisited by someone in late 2020 to confirm that this game breaking bug still exists 6 years after release. Icing on the cake, they said it affects the other two titles in the SR trilogy of games, also. I went from being excited that I had something to play for many hours with mods to never wanting to touch again. Absolutely unacceptable.

I really like Shadowrun Hong Kong, but this was is just worse in every way compared to that one. 
The next one I will play will be Dragonfall and I assume I will like it better than this one since I can compare it to this one.

90140197.review:
So I played the Shadowrun games slightly out of order yet that did not hamper my enjoyment of Shadowrun Returns.  For those unfamiliar with this series Shadowrun started out as a tabletop RPG and has seamlessly made the transition into a computer RPG series thanks to the team at Harebrained Schemes.  These are very much story-driven games featuring a brilliant tactical combat system to support the gameplay.  I loved Shadowrun Dragonfall when I played through it close to five years ago and I finally got the chance to play the Returns, the first game in the series.  As someone who likes to play lots of different games it is always a challenge to commit myself to a lengthy RPG.  That said I find the Shadowrun universe such a interesting setting and I'm so glad I had the chance to revisit it.

Shadowrun Returns starts when you get a video message on your computer from someone you used go running with.  See shadow runners are freelancers who get paid to do other peoples dirty work.  Turns out your friend Sam has met his end and he is offering you a reward if you can find out who killed him.  If working for a dead man isn't interesting enough you start to unravel much bigger plots at play.  You'll start by investigating the local bar where Sam used to spend much of his time at.  Conveniently this bar happens to be a great place to pick up some jobs and the supplies need to go along with them.  Eventually you meet one of Sam's relatives and find out they have ties to the Universal Brotherhood, a religious organization which, after some investigating, appears to have some nasty secrets going on behind the scenes.


You'll spend an equal amount of time or more in battle as you will reading the massive script that makes up the storyline.  Shadowrun Returns is a tactical strategy game where you'll find your team and the opposing forces on a large grid often compose of multiple rooms and scattered furniture.  You and your opponents takes turns and on your turn each of your characters usually have two actions they can take.  Whether you move, attack, or use an ability these each will take one action point.  When you go to attack an enemy you see a percentage of the chance that you'll land a hit on them.  This percentage has many factors that go into it such as the distance between you and your foe, your proficiency level with your weapon, and whether your opponent is out in the open or behind cover.

Only your main character will you need to level up stats for as all your other companions you'll just hire from the local network of available shadow runners.  There are some major skills such as Quickness, Strength, Intelligence, and Willpower.  Each of these skills has subcategories which can only be leveled up to as far as you have leveled the overlapping skill.  This means it will probably be best to focus on two or three areas to specialize in rather than attempt to be a jack of all trades.  There are different archetypes that specialize in close quarters combat, magic abilities, decking (hacking), summoning spirits, and rigging drones.  Having a team that compliments your own skills and gives you flexibility in combat is key to surviving the rather unforgiving scenarios throughout the game.

I've always enjoy tactical RPGs from Final Fantasy Tactics Advance to Banner Saga and I can confidently say that the Shadowrun series can easily stand with the greats.  What is most unique about Shadowrun is the incredible universe the games are set in which combines cyberpunk and fantasy in a wholly-believable modern setting.  Even aside from the deep and fascinating storytelling is a equally complex but manageable combat system and character progression.  As you barely get through one fight to another each new upgrade you receive feels like a godsend and will provide just the edge you need to survive your next encounter.  There is a lot of reading to get through to enjoy the storyline but if you don't mind that and wish to sink your teeth into a deeply rewarding tactical RPG look no farther than Shadowrun Returns.

88826411.review:
[h1] A slow start but the combat can be fun and the art design is cool [/h1]

Turn-based RPGs can be a slog, especially if the combat easily gets repetitive. Shadowrun Returns at least offers diversity in engaging battles, since there’s also plenty of options in character creation. But there’s still some pacing issues in the beginning. And if it wasn’t for the fascinating setting and great artwork, I probably would’ve given up sooner. Thankfully, the narrative escalates not too long and does end in places for further expansion.

I mainly play for the story. And I was hoping that Shadowrun would be exceptional because of its interesting blend of swords-and-sorcery fantasy and Neoromancer-esque cyberpunk themes. 

Shadowrun Returns takes place in a futuristic but decadent Seattle in 2054. The world is ran by large corporations and a growing cult with humans and mythical races and creatures, such as elves, dwarves, orks (sic), and trolls. A fascinating setting with many possibilities to explore, right? But after finishing it thought, I can’t really say that I was fully satisfied nor downright disappointed. It’s.. just ok. 

There are factors that may have contributed to what I feel about the plot. The writing can be awkward at times (they switch the f-word with “frag” and sh** with “drek”) and the pacing can be slow. But the dialogue isn’t awful too and does have its moments, and they aren’t few. As for the pacing, this is only an issue to me at the start where they seem to attempt to do some worldbuilding and tone-setting through exposition. Furthermore, the title does have DLCs so perhaps I can try those out to get a better look into its world and lore.

Its combat system also balances out the shortcomings of the narrative. There’s plenty of ways to go about a battle because of the diversity of its character creation—another good thing about the game. Players can choose a path of magic or technology. And this doesn’t mean a predictable dichotomy of melee and ranged attacks, by the way. You can opt to be a sword-wielding ork that can withstand magic assaults or become an elf decker (hacker) who can be destructive when infiltrating the matrix.

Perhaps the best thing I like about this game is the artwork. Though it depicts a somewhat pessimistic outlook of the future, Shadowrun Returns offers tons of great design in landscape and architecture. Because of this, it perfectly contributes to the tone and atmosphere of the game.

Having said that, another thing that bums me out is that there’s very little exploration. I suppose I should have done my homework on this end, but I expected it to be an open-world or something close to that. But it’s not. So you only get to see a small portion of Seattle. Still, it isn’t a major issue to me.

I'll consider trying out the additional content. But for Shadowrun Returns, it's a decent 12- to 15-hour RPG if you just want to finish the main story. I can definitely see people spending more time trying out other builds and finishing the side quests. 

3/5

86912545.review:
I suppose there's nothing really wrong with this title. It's very well written. The action is true enough to the table top game, the options pretty well reflect what's present there. Sure, there's a lot to like about this. I just can't take that step to recommend this title to other gamers.

In some ways it feels like the original top-down Fallout games got a Shadowrun mod. In a world where Cyberpunk 2077 exists now it's impossible for me to say this title did Shadowrun enough justice. Sure, CP2077 didn't  either - Cyberpunk is it's own material after all, written about the same time as SR from what I've read on the matter. But seeing how well that game can realize what Shadowrun should be it's hard to really recommend this to folks who'd rather experience Shadowrun.

Yeah, the skin is Shadowrun. The writing reads Shadowrun. The game itself plays like old Fallout. It's not open enough, not free enough. It's too linear. There aren't enough choices, not enough ways to solve problems and come up with your own solutions. It's a very good attempt given the game engine. I just wish they found ways to make it truer to the title. It's not Shadowrun, it's a Shadowrun story.

I don't think I can look at this title through a different prism, as if I never played any Shadowrun title before. Does it work as a standalone game? Yeah, I guess so. I didn't finish this game; I'm more likely to finish Dragonfall than this. The original Fallouts were more compelling than this. Maybe if they took more cues from that this would've been better. It needed a bigger scope, a more true representation. Good effort, just not good enough for me to recommend.

86868407.review:
While I don't think I'm in love with this game, I did enjoy my time with it. It feels very much like a competent bioware-esque RPG before they went to shit. I love the setting of it being a fusion of fantasy and cyberpunk dystopia though.

I just wish the game itself spent more time on world building, but it pretty much focuses exclusively on the plot with a few side plots with the characters/

I think overall, if I have to put a number on it, I'd give it a 7/10. The gameplay and way you can build your character is pretty varied but the lack of impact that positioning has on the combat makes it less complex than it should be.

And another gameplay element that I wish was more developed was the mercenary hiring system but my idea of what it should be would probably make the game fundamentally different because I'd want it at least developed to the point of being like MGSV's background base system so there maybe I would be asking for too much or something that's not really what the game is about.

The main highlight of the game for me were the quests where you have to do corporate espionage that isn't just 'Go kill thing for banker man'.

But I'd recommend it for anyone who likes RPG's with lots of dialogue checks akin to FNV because there's a metric fuckton of them. Or someone who'd enjoy combat that's akin to the current generation X-Com games that's easier to manage. It's fairly short for an RPG though which is dissapointing, I finished it in roughly 16 hours, but there's replay value in it because the classes do actually pretty differently from one another so if you do one campaign for each class you'd probably get 50ish hours out of it.

85672005.review:
Do NOT purchase this version because Shadowrun Dragonfall has an *optimized* remake of it.

[h1]Never trust a dead man.[/h1]

Shadowrun Returns is the desktop version of the tabletop Shadowrun rpg. Additionally, it's shipped with an official campaign called Dead Man's Switch. Therefore, I'll split this review into two parts: one is for the gameplay and the other is for the official campaign.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Overall, the gameplay is inspiring at first but deteriorates later due to the lack of balance. On the one hand, it offers you so many races and classes which seem to derive lots of possibilities, on the other hand, the combat system disables most of them. Ranged samurais predominate the battle field, eclipsing the mages, shamans and riggers (the class who use drones in a combat).
Why do I attach so much importance on the combat system? That's because the others are irrelevant compared with the combat. You don't have to restart when you have no one to deck (the hacking in this game) or to convince the npc, because the campaign always leaves another approach as an alternative. However, when you lose a combat, you lose literally and have to restart. In other words, the combat system dominates the others.
This does NOT mean the game is unbalanced, though. On the contrary, the game gives you many extra options by adding these subordinate systems and can surprise you very often when you're not playing as a gunner. "Inspiring" , as I said before.
The unbalanced system is actually the combat system itself. Mages can wield powerful magic, shamans can summon devastating spirits and riggers can deploy versatile drones. However, mages suffer from long skill cooldown and high missing penalty, shamans' spirits can accidentally escape as an new enemy and riggers' drones are expensive comparing runners for hire. Besides, deckers can only control gunturrets in few cases (not drones deployed by your enemies), while eloquence is totally useless during combat. Nevertheless, close combat is risky and ill-advised because of the mechanism of overwatching. Generally speaking, gunners are too strong to be defeated. I played as a dwarf decker who also specialized in pistols at first, ending up as a pistol user who had a few tricks in decking :-\
This game features an additional set of combat called decking, which takes place in a cyber-world. Some may find it innovative while others get annoyed. 
Apart from these shortcomings, the combat system of this game is similar to XCOM series, including "99% then miss" :-P . Thus you can enjoy it if you like both XCOM series and text-based rpgs. And this game has a "save rewinding" mechanism, which allows you to recover your deleted saves, which really saved me once.

[h1]Official Campaign[/h1]
Now let's switch to the dead man's switch. Generally speaking, it's an ordinary whodunit with several gameplay bugs (personally, I only experienced once and it was negated by frequently saving). Thanks to the vast setting of Shadowrun and the diversity in the combat system, the campaign is still interesting enough to be enjoyed.
The artwork is excellent. It's challenging to create harmony when cyber elements collide with magic, but they succeeded. Soundtracks seem a little repetitive but not annoying.
The quality of the official campaign became worse after mid-game, which might be attributed to rushing. Some typing error occurred in some late-game dialogues, such as "the the only one" and " by the by". [b](Spoiler warning)[/b] What disappointed me most was [spoiler]the insufficient description of Lynne, the female elf cousin. On the basis of the description, she had no motives to enter such a cult. In my opinion, it makes this deliberately designed story with nesting conspiracy incomplete. [/spoiler]Despite this, the story is well-crafted with plenty of decisions waiting to be made. It captures the spirit of cyberpunk, and can be further improved with voice-acting.

As a Kickstarter project, Shadowrun Returns is not a disappointment. However, it's not extraordinary, either. The enriched gameplay system is not well balanced thus it's hard to say that there is replay value in this game even with Workshop contents. The official campaign seems more like an unfinished masterpiece.
Or maybe I'm too harsh on an indie game.

3/5 Enjoyable

83921397.review:
[h1] In short[/h1] 
A poor story, a rather boring "roleplay" part, but fights are interesting enough.
If you can get it for cheap (less than 5€/$/£), this very short game will entertain you a bit, but don't count on replayability.
I don't feel bad about buying it because I had it for cheap. Had it been full price, I'd be very disappointed.


First observation, it's a [i]very[/i] short game : I'm 10 hours in and I only have 3 missions left.

[h1] Story[/h1]
	Not very interesting. I won't spoil too much, but let's just say the antagonistic party is very plain.


[h1] Gameplay[/h1] 
It's divided in two elements : The fight and the "point and click investigation". I won't call it roleplay.
Point and click investigation
	You click on interactible elements on the map to collect clues or find passwords, then talk to NPCs to progress the plot.
	It's mostly time filler to increase the game duration, but that brings very little to the game. It's interesting at first, but gets tedious real quick. And on a second playthrough they become a chore.
	You barely need to read the dialogs and descriptions, and when you do, it's not very interesting. Pro Tip : if text story is an important part of your gameplay, try to make it interesting.

Fights
	Simple and effective. Not much to say : You move your characters, use their abilities and pray for good RNG. Sometimes the interface is a little clunky but in general it works.
	On normal, the fight difficulty is weird : I made a specialized tank and he wiped the floor with every enemy encountered, on the other hand, the stat distribution of your team is quite weak, so even the gunfighter you hire will underperform in the fight. At least, shamans and mages will have useful utility spells.

[h1] Replayability[/h1] 
	If you can tolerate the tedium of point and click "roleplay", then you can try new builds, otherwise, it's pointless.

82819538.review:
DISCLAIMER: I usually review games after I've finished them (or at least the main quest). However, I believe I have a solid grasp on what makes this game special so I've decided to review it only six hours into the game. Some of my pros/cons may or may not extend throughout the entire game.

---

Shadowrun Returns is an exceptionally atmospheric cyberpunk RPG. Alluring neon colors are balanced by the dull grays of the concrete jungle. A murder mystery blossoms into a much more complex scenario that delves into the dark themes that are signature to this genre. The soundtrack evokes mystery and a sense of modern wonder. Tie this together with one of the more intriguing cyberpunk franchises out there and you have a great recipe for an instant classic of a video game.

Don't go in expecting a Deus Ex or Cyberpunk 2077; this game is linear almost to a fault. There is virtually zero exploration and the storylines don't really branch beyond some basic choice-and-consequence. The greatest shame to this linearity is the fact that the Shadowrun franchise is extremely compelling. It marries traditional fantasy with the dystopian themes of the cyberpunk genre, creating a world that has literal technomancy: magic and technology together. This is a fresh concept, indeed, as most cyberpunk content focuses more on the classic definition of "high tech, low life". Shadowrun takes that and blends it with mystic elements to create something that truly stands out among the genre. As a result, I just want to take my time and really explore the world and concept that Jordan Weisman devised.. but due to this game's linearity, the full extent of this exploration is limited to simply looking at the game world as I progress through it. Fortunately, this game's art is phenomenal.

That leads me to point out two of the game's strongest points: storytelling and atmosphere. Due to the linearity of the game, the story is very focused. It's not about accumulating side quests and grinding to max levels. This game is about creating a character you want to play and then progressing through a great story, meeting memorable characters and just soaking in the exceptional cyberpunk atmosphere. Despite being an isometric RPG, this game has absolutely zero trouble immersing me fully into the world. The game's story does a solid job of not only immersing the player into the world but it also really serves to teach new players the core principles and lore of the series. That's something that not every game can pull off easily. The atmosphere constantly gives the player the feeling of living in a near-future world where technology and society have gone wrong; with magic added to the mix, it truly gives the game an ambient sense of oppression, like society is truly teetering on the edge of total collapse.

I should also mention that the game's combat system is actually quite solid. I'm NOT a fan of turn-based combat systems at all (with the exception of Larian's Divinity: Original Sin games). That being said, Shadowrun Returns' combat system is simplistic in a great way and manages to somehow avoid many of the things that typically frustrate me about this sort of combat. I've seen many compare the game's combat to XCOM and while I own an XCOM game, I have yet to play it so I can't really speak as to the accuracy of that comparison. All I CAN say, however, is that it gives me classic Fallout vibes, minus some of the really irritating aspects of those games' combat systems. It's a simple as action points that determine how far you can maneuver and whether or not you can even fire your weapon. It's certainly nowhere near Larian's level of brilliance but it serves its purpose well. I've never once felt irritated/frustrated by this game's combat which is a MAJOR accomplishment for a turn-based combat system, in my book.

Overall, as long as you go in with realistic expectations and as long as you have at least a passing interest in the cyberpunk genre, I'm certain you'll enjoy this game. I actually bought this game well over a year ago in response to my first bit of interest that I had toward the then-upcoming Cyberpunk 2077 and it served as a pretty decent introduction to the genre. I followed it up by buying the rest of the trilogy and the entire Deus Ex series and now, with 2077 finally out, I consider myself to be quite a passionate fan of this genre of fiction... but I digress, this game is fantastic and I definitely recommend it. Just remember that this isn't Fallout, Baldur's Gate, etc. It's very linear, but it's extremely well-written and soaked with cyberpunk atmosphere. If you're looking for a fun game to play on the side while enjoying Cyberpunk 2077, or just want to give this genre a shot, definitely consider grabbing this one!

I want to preface my review by saying that I'm not a Shadowrun fan.  I got this game because I'm an RPG fan and will buy almost any RPG game.  I didn't really understand much of the Shadowrun world so I can't really comment on that - someone who is a fan, might enjoy it.

However, as an RPG fan, I can't say that I really did.  It's a short, basic game.  There are supposed to be different ways to build a character (and hire runners to balance the party out) and certain stats can let you do things differently (maybe find a different route, get more money, etc.).  Yet, the game never really captivated me (again it might just be because I'm not a Shadowrun fan) and I ended up just using cheats to buff my character (i.e. all money and karma I needed). It felt like even cheats didn't make much difference in the long run - I never felt like i was in danger of dying, seeing all available options just showed that while different ways of doing things was nice in theory, it never really felt meaningful (just more like the game made it so you would never be locked out of something no matter your build).

Combat felt just too slow for my tastes.  My main issue was that once in mission, you are always in turn base, which meant it took a long time for you to gather your party together so you can move into the next room as a group instead of just one person who would get slaughtered.  I prefer games were you are only turn based while actually in combat, but real time when outside it so it didn't take forever to move around.

I loved this game, I am happy of finding this gem.
PRO
- The story is linear. Yes it is a pro because since it is all text-based, I do not get too distracted and I can really pay attention to the lore. When there are too many side quests, and tons of text to read (like Divinity, which I love anyway) I loose context and forget things, this never happens in this game. The story is simple but it captured my attention for the entire game. 
- The combat is hard enough (normal difficulty) to keep me concentrated but, at the same time, it is not too complicated to cause any rage-quit.
- The drones were a lot of fun. I love this type of builds, but only few games have this class (rigger) so it was a nice surprise to have an "engineer-like" character.

CON
- The karma system is not very intuitive. It is not clear what advances every new point gives you. I needed to follow a guide to understand the skills and what they gave (btw, there are not that many guides online).
- Some bugs are very annoying. I had to do a quest without my drones to avoid a loop.
- This is not really a con, it is more a suggestion for new players: save.the.hell.out.of.this.game. Sometimes I did not consider that with that team I would not be able to kill certain NPCs, so I had to load a previous save... and sometimes I did not save often enough.

Overall, I will play all the other Shadowrun games, I hope they will be as good as this one!

81533503.review:
Podría decirse que Shadowrun Returns es el juego de rol más lineal y corto del género. Aunque yo no lo consideraría 'rol' del todo y lo metería más bien dentro del saco de títulos similares a XCOM.

Tengo sentimientos encontrados con la obra, que me ha dejado buen sabor de boca entre muchas puntillas que no acaban de gustarme del todo. Como resultado de un Kickstarter puedo decir que promete mucho llevar a videojuego este sistema y no han hecho un mal trabajo, pero se nota que ha quedado muchísimo por pulir/añadir. En las doce horas que me ha durado acabar la campaña (algo que como ya he dicho me resulta poco) he encontrado una traducción al español penosa plagada de erratas, muchísimos bugs y poca libertad limitada a los escasos y pequeños mapas por los que moverse. Aviso, con cierta dureza, que el control y los menús resultan algo engorrosos, más cuando has terminado un combate y estás obligado a seguir realizando acciones por turnos. Es un detalle infumable.

Para empezar dejo claro que resulta mejor darle caña en inglés sin dudarlo, ya que la traducción llega a puntos que te marean o pierdes el hilo de la trama. El argumento de la obra es genial y el punto fuerte que me empuja a recomendarlo, con un par de compañeros y NPCs carismáticos que te da tiempo a encariñarte aunque no de disfrutar. Sin embargo, y aquí es donde voy a empezar a lanzar piedras, en la breve experiencia me he topado con muchas cosas que dificultan disfrutarlo.

Ya de base hay un bug bastante molesto que deja la partida en medio de un combate, sin pasar entre turnos, obligando a cerrar el juego y cargar la escena por donde guardaste antes de la susodicha batalla. Me ha pasado un par de veces y si es una pelea larga sienta como una patada en el centro de gravedad. Además de eso la música da errores y se solapa si por ejemplo estas con un Decker surfeando por la Matriz o los enemigos a veces actuan de forma bastante extraña, exponiéndose a los ataques debido a una IA muy básica que no cambia aunque aumentes la dificultad. Como resultado el juego es muy fácil. He llevado un elfo samurai de melee sin hechizo alguno y muchos implantes que no han conseguido tumbarme ni una sola vez en toda la campaña. Sabía de antemano que lo suyo era un Adepto para ese tipo de personaje pero tiré de Samurai Callejero (que aquí suelen llevar armas de fuego, lo que me hace dudar de la denominación 'Samurai') solo para demostrar que a base de golpes en seco podía acabarlo.

Dicho esto también carece de contenido y variables. Donde hay que interactuar en cada mapa viene marcado dejando las posibilidades bien obvias como si llevaras anteojeras para caballos, por lo que solo hay que seguir las marcas realzando que tu avance es una línea recta. Hay muy poco armamento y armaduras que me dan la sensación que son como la tapa dura que cubre un verdadero sistema de rol y por su brevedad tienes acceso a ellas en cero coma. Siquiera voy a mencionar la carencia de misiones secundarias, una perla muy gorda.

Y ya por último, pero no menos importante, hay clases que son prácticamente inútiles en la campaña. Un claro ejemplo es el Decker, que solo necesitas de verdad uno en todo el juego y te lo consigue un NPC. Eso de meterte en la Matriz es flipante, pero he llevado uno a la misión final como resultado tuve un runner inútil, aunque como ha sido fácil no fue problema alguno. Todo lo demás es divertido de viciar aunque con evidentes diferencias en cuanto a eficacia, pero como montas tu grupo antes de cada misión puedes probar distintos formatos de equipo que se adapten a tu estilo y así equilibrar la balanza.

En definitiva recomiendo darle un tiento aunque no esperes nada del calibre o complejidad que portan los clásicos del género. Aunque puedes subir con karma los atributos, habilidades y hechizos del personaje, eso es lo máximo que encontrarás para tener tu chute rolero. Yo jugué una vez a Shadowrun (2e o 3e), ya que soy de D&D, y lo recuerdo mucho más extenso y completo en comparación. Además, las opciones de diálogo son escasas (quitando alguna opción extra depende del Carisma y el atributo al que esté ligada) y todas ellas llevan prácticamente a lo mismo. Eso sí, tengo que probar Dragonfall y Hong Kong porque han pulido los puntos débiles que tiene la primera entrega y huelo llevarme más de una sorpresa. Shadowrun Returns es para echar un rato y la rejugabilidad es escasa o nula. Eso sí, la ambientación es más que flipante.
