81228417.review:
Shadowrun Returns - Dead Man's Switch is an isometric RPG game with turn-based squad tactical combat (see xcom) in a cyberpunk meets fantasy setting.

The game starts with you receiving a message from Sam Watts, your fellow friend. Sam died and before he died he recorded this video so that you could track down his killer and get a reward if you find them and bring them to justice. A detective story unfolds as you are trying to find out who killed him and why. The game will just immerse you in the story which is very well written and is also lots of fun (with lot of references to previous games and lore).

After you find the killer and find out why Sam was killed you will also uncover a horrific fact about a cult that wants to bring extraplanar creatures into the realm that would most probably just devastate it. The problem? These creatures are pretty much immortal unless you get your hands on a special prototype weapon that can kill these spirits. The final fight is probably the biggest downside of the game. You need too kill the creature with conventional weapons first (or Magic or spirits). Next round it will turn into a spirit that is immune to all this but the prototype weapon. You've got that one round to hit it 3 times in order to kill it and you've got max. 80% chance of actually hitting if you are standing close enough. You've got two shots before you need to reload and have 2 (max. 3) characters with this weapon. If you don't succeed it will turn into a physical creature again and you gotta try again. The final fight thus is rather annoying and long. 

As for the graphics, I really like the hand painted ones but the 3d models felt a bit bland. The graphics in overall creates a good and fitting atmosphere for the game.

Music and sound effects is another story. This might be just me but I have to say that both were rather jarring. While the sound effects are ok in terms of not sounding totally out of place they still didn't sound quite right for my ears. The music I didn't enjoy at all. There is no voice acting. 

There are two parts to gameplay. The game is story driven so mostly you will be reading dialogues and descriptions of scenes or characters. Depending on how your character is build (which skills it has) you might be able to choose different answer or actions. My character turned out to be charismatic Decker specialized in melee combat. The reason was that thanks to high Charisma I got to talk my way through dialogues, being a hacker allowed me to do some necessary running around Matrix safely. Being good in combat is probably a necessity since you will go on runs that will sooner or later end up being pure tactical turn-based combat. You will have 1-4 characters to your disposal. Each character has action points that you can spend each turn to either move (and attack), move, attack, use magic, summon spirits, use items. You can hide behind object to make it harder for your enemies to shoot you. You also need a good line of sight and distance to actually hit. Flanking is also something to consider. If all your squad will end up in one place you are certainly going to get hit by a grenade.

The game on the default difficulty is very easy so you don't need to worry about spending karma (the points that are spent to level up your skills) in a wrong way. The HUD is very basic but shows well your equipment and skills. You have a limited number of slots for everything, if you have more items they will go to your stash. You can either get items from your stash by physically going there or enter it when buying/selling stuff. At the beginning of each part of the story you will be allowed to change the stuff in your inventory so you don't need to go back in between chapters.

Verdict
Shadowrun Returns is well polished game for a kickstarted funded game and it did the original p&p Shadowrun justice. It has a nice and well written story that has a twist that some may not enjoy that much. It has certain but limited amount of RPG elements, you can choose your class, learn skills and develop them. You can buy equipment, spells etc. The combat is tactical and turn-based, a pretty much a copy of X-com combat system. One of the things I enjoyed is walking in the Matrix (uses the same combat system).

The not so good things about the game is that the story is very linear and the world is not really open. You can walk around a bit but you can't interact much outside of the main story. You also hire runners for each run and you can't change equipment or develop their skills.

In general, this game is a relatively short adventure game that introduces one to the world of Shadowrun, tactical combat and some RPG elements.

I'm not entirely sure to whom I'd recommend the game. I'd say that players like me who spent hours and hours playing Shadowrun in the past will enjoy this game. I'd also probably recommend this game to players that don't have much experience with gaming or are looking for an easy game to play.

81184373.review:
Took me 9.9 hours to clear it on normal. Everything is great fun up until the last mission, which is an hour-long slog through a gauntlet of foes. I cannot stress enough how emotionally harrowing this gauntlet is:
-only your combat stats will matter. don't bring a deck, don't bring a shaman (for anything other than utility casting), don't hope to benefit from your etiquette dips, don't expect anything but fight after fight after fight.
-roughly two-thirds of the enemies you'll face will revive! into ghostly forms that need to be put down in a single round. fail that, and those ghosts will revive, in turn, into the original enemies, back up to 40 hp. this cycle can repeat endlessly.
-those ghostly foes also have 40 hp. they take damage 15 hp at a time, from a "weapon" that can hurt these things.
-remember that bit about combat stats mattering? this weapon is a special weapon. it cannot crit. it cannot become more accurate than 80%--it cannot scale with any of your combat stats. you're looking at a 60-80% chance to hit depending on how far you are. also, it's only got two shots.
-those enemies need three shots to go down.
-you do have two or three guns (if you pay for the third) split amongst your party, sure, but a lot of your action points will still get tied up in reloading, repositioning, and missing
-oh my god is the last mission a slog
-you're probably best off playing up until you realize you're heading into/playing the last mission, and then looking up the ending
-seriously though, everything up until that point is pretty fun.
I recommend this game if you can stomach skipping the last mission, playing the last mission despite its cruelty, or enjoy building character concepts in a fairly flexible system and taking them partway through a game before restarting to try a new build
I make the assumption that most people fit at least one of the above criteria, so I recommend the game overall, but you really shouldn't go into the final chapter with anything but the most miserable of expectations.

80138780.review:
Shadowrun Returns features a single campaign, Dead Man's Switch, and an editor, which lets you build your own custom maps and quests.

The campaign is a tactical turn-based RPG, with its main focus being on the narrative.

In its RPG aspect, I enjoyed how fluid it was with its class system, which allowed you to dip into other classes as you desired whenever you got enough experience points. You can choose to be a gunner, blade, hacker, etc, as well as more magic. You can also choose to modify your body with tech, but doing so causes you to lose touch with magic, if you choose to go that route. 
The class system is not tied to the narrative, but certain activities require skills checks, the most common of which I encountered are intelligence/hacking/strength skill checks. I wish there were a few more skill checks in more narrative influencing setups that pushed you in a other directions. As it is, you can just go pure hacker and most of the story will be cake walk for you. The story parts, not the combat.

The tactical turn-based gameplay is how all the combat in this game is done. You get a set amount of action points and you cycle through your team, then the enemy does the same. Before most missions, you will be given a chance to purchase teammates to deploy, but you only get them for that one mission, which I didn't like much, as I didn't get a chance to bond with them. You do get a few recurring characters and they gorw on your a bit.
But what I really, really hated was the % hit chance this game employs. It plays like Xcom, where you get a % chance to hit depending on how far you are from the enemy, and unless you have leveled up that combat style, you will miss a lot. It is best to pick one weapon style, be it swords, guns, or magic, and stick with it, as you don't have the inventory space to hold multiple weapons.

I would say that the inventory management in this game is a bit frustrating, as you need to be in the home hub to swap equipment. Also, enemies will not drop equipment. At best, you will find frag grenades in the occasional box, but you will mostly be rewarded with money for completing missions.

If the text is small on a 1920x1080 monitor, change the ingame resolution to 1360x768.

78993653.review:
[b]Shadowrun Retuns[/b] is a fun and immersive isometric RPG with an interesting detective story and turn-based combat. It's based on a tabletop game with rich lore, set in a universe that combines cyberpunk and high fantasy elements. It has inspired a few 16-bit games in the 90's that had enough following to succesfully fund a [i]Kickstarter[/i] campaign that resulted in this video game. There's also plenty of references to those retro games that fans of the franchise will appreciate. But you don't have to be familiar with the lore to enjoy the game. I wasn't, but still understood what's what.

The progression is linear, which might be a problem for some, but I actually liked that, because I didn't have to spend time backtracking, and all the explorable bits were conveniently placed on the way towards the mission objectives. The missions are really well designed (with multiple stages, not too rushed, not tedious, with fun little twists). You just start the game and immerse into the story. The levels are intricate and detailed, conveying a cyberpunk atmosphere similar to [b]Deus Ex[/b], but with magic and metahumans (elves, dwarves, orcs, trolls). The game features 6 main classes (archetypes), which all are well balanced and, along with the equipment options, offer a 50/50  choice between magic and tech.

[b]Shadowrun Returns[/b] is also relatively easy, and, as such, serves as a good introduction to turn-based squad games. If you have previously played games like [b]X-COM[/b], this will be a walk in the park for you.

Furthermore, [b]Shadowrun Returns[/b] has a level editor and numerous mods. After finishing the main game, you can explore the community mods, many of which are full-scale campaigns with detailed stories. Or, if you have the patience and time, you can design your own. The level editor is intuitive and relatively easy-to-learn.

I really don't have anything bad to say about [b]Shadowrun Returns[/b]. For what it is, it's great.

But for the game as a whole, for the experience and fun factor, [b]I give it[/b]: [u]8/10[/u].

77963081.review:
Took me a while, but I finally got to play this game some 4 years after getting it in a Humble bundle. Got to play it because I had no idea what to play, a full library and this was second in the recommended queue.
Tl;dr: the game is good, but mostly because of the immersion.
And now for the longer version. I'll start with the bad parts, The combat is rather simplistic, not very challenging after a certain point (played on medium though, would suggest the hardest difficulty as I played the sequels on hard and it was still quite easy). The big plot twist in the story does feel somehow artificial. The game is quite short. I finished the whole campaign in less than 15 hours and I am very much the completionist type. Only had one go at it with a smoothtalking elven sharpshooter with augments. May or may not revisit at some point, mainly because it's so short and I can try out builds.
The great selling point of the game is the world and the immersion. Getting contracts for dirty work against corporations in 2054 is fun fun fun. Also, there's human augmentation and a reasonably fresh approach on magic. Despite its shortcomings, it leaves you with a feeling of wanting more at the end. 
All in all, would recommend mainly as an appetizer for the series, as there are a number of moments in the sequels that will get *Leonardo DiCaprio pointing at the screen* reactions or make you smile a bit. 
Small spoiler: the sequels are MUCH better.
Briefly tried user-created campaigns, not a big fan. Played it with the deluxe DLC, no idea what that brings to the game. Don't pay full price for it.
Stick to the shadows or whatever.

Just like a lot of people writing a review for this, I was a massive fan of the SNES and Genesis games! And every title in the new series, including Returns, hold a great candle to it's lineage.

The story is set in this cyberpunk neo-noir world filled with fantasy elements such has the races (orcs, dwarfs, elves etc), magic and class of characters that are on display. This is highlighted particularly in the great writing and dialogue told through the isometric world constructed with the sci-fi design. Overall, everything is very true to all the source material and will be a hit if it slightly interests you.

The game-play will have no trouble grabbing you if you are a turn-based RPG fan. Even though the journey in this one is fairly linear, you are given an array of options to help tackle each situation. That plus a simple but deep interface and progression system makes this one a blast!

I have to admit, Returns is a bit too linear for my liking. But it serves as a health introduction to the series as it'll give you a great appreciation for the Shadowrun world. A must have on sale, worth the  full price if it slightly catches your eye.

77198113.review:
The weakest of the three Shadowrun games by Harebrained schemes, you can pretty much skip this one and jump straight into Dragonfall unless you're a completionist or you want to get into the mods.

In terms of mods, this is actually the best of the three, since the largest number of mods are available for the OG Shadowrun Returns. But in terms of the main campaign, this is very much a "first iteration" that the sequels improve upon in every way. The gameplay is a bit more janky and the storyline is OK, but doesn't really aspire to much greatness. Probably the best thing about it is that the character from the SNES Shadowrun game, Jake Armitage, shows up as an ally here. There are also some story beats and characters that show up in the two sequels that show up here first.

So, oddly, I would only recommend picking this game up AFTER you've tried Dragonfall or Hong Kong and liked them in order to complete the trilogy and get access to more mod content, but as a standalone I say you're safe skipping this one.

The lack of choices do not matter much, though I did notice that, in some cases, if I had increased my charisma, I would get certain dialogue options available. This would've been fine, had it not been for the fact that I still got the same choices despite my lack of charisma. I simply had to keep the dialogue going for a little bit longer before I had the option. I also feel like some skills were wasted, charisma being one of them. I chose to play as a mage, but found myself just using a gun most of the time. Perhaps this is just me, but I feel as if they didn't do the mages properly here.

To keep things short... Good combat, decent world, decent story. Skills could've been utilized better. Overall, it's a relatively short, but sweet game. The saving and checkpoints in this game are awful. You will find yourself repeating a lot, since you can't save in the middle of something.

Trying really hard to appreciate it as some revolutionary video game adaptation of a board game. But after actually playing XCOM, similar in combat, and other rpgs, Shadowrun falls short in execution.

IMO, the biggest issue is inconsistency with probability and the number displayed. Maybe I'm going crazy, but the %'s do not appear to be accurate to the actual probability. I find things like using the right range when it's an S, M or L attack will give you a better shot. It's also really stupid how some characters are point blank and still 50% or worse! And 50% hit 2 out of 5 or worse. You definitely get a bonus from backstab that's not reflected in the %. But getting a backstab is almost impossible in the game because the characters turn around if you run around them. Sure, that's fine because why wouldn't they, but then why implement it? The only time you get backstab is when you attack from multiple angles, but if you are in that position, you're most likely already winning. And in this game, you never attack from multiple angles, usually the enemy reinforcements get the flank on you as the infiltrator. It is also so bizarre how we are using guns but it can end up in weak, normal, crit, and often times you get weak simply because they are facing your character.

It doesn't have all the bells and whistles of XCOM (not that it requires it), but the story/writing is also juvenile. It was great when you're just starting out and getting hooked in to the Shadowrun universe. But the way they weave in the plot with the mediocre combat just doesn't work out in the long run.

And at the point where I'm reviewing the game, I think conversation locks using epithets and attribute levels is a joke in the game. You don't get much, just a minor alternative to progress through the same story. Like a little extra gold or saves you some combat.

I want to say it's between a thumbs up and thumbs down? It's worth it enough to finish what is a story in a unique universe. But there are a lot of things wrong with it that if you can't love the first 20 minutes, you probably won't like it at all.

[h1][b]Bueno[/b][/h1]
[b]Historia.[/b] Debemos resolver un asesinato, iniciando una investigación que a su vez nos permitirá conocer muchos personajes interesantes. Bien llevada, con ciertos giros de guión e intriga, aunque un tanto previsible. Hay mucho para leer, al estilo Pillars of Eternity, y aunque podamos tomar decisiones que modifican la forma de proceder, el resultado final no varía.

[b]Escenarios.[/b] Ideales para crear una ambientación cyberpunk. Al tener perspectiva isométrica cada mapa es como una ilustración. Están muy cuidados y detallados.

[b]RPG[/b] Podemos crear nuestro personaje para hacerle cumplir un rol específico dentro del grupo. Por supuesto según invirtamos puntos en los atributos adecuados obtendremos nuevas habilidades.

[b]Estrategia.[/b] A la hora de luchar tendremos un estilo muy similar a XCOM. Las acciones que llevemos a cabo vendrán determinadas por la cantidad de puntos de acción que podremos realizar por turno.

[h1][b]Malo[/b][/h1]
[b]Cybermagia.[/b] La mezcla resultante entre el cyberpunk y la magia es cuanto menos curiosa. También contamos con criaturas fantásticas como Elfos, Orkos, Enanos y Trolls. Dos elementos difíciles de combinar. No me ha convencido.

[b]Exploración.[/b] Los mapas son cortos y fáciles de explorar. Sin embargo no encontraremos ningún tipo de loot interesante. Al jugar como hacker, piratear terminales nos da acceso a información extra.

[b]Compañeros.[/b] Aunque podamos contratar runners (hasta 3) para cumplir con las misiones, no podremos editarlos. Vienen con equipo y estadísticas propias.

[h1][b]Nota: B[/b][/h1]

75917231.review:
A cheap and fun RPG, but nothing particularly deep or engaging. The setting is interesting and the dialogue is generally well-written, with an engaging story and some nice twists, even if the twists aren't particularly unexpected.

For character progression, you don't really get enough points to really specialise in too many fields. If you try to cover too much ground, you'll wind up at the end of the game with a character who isn't really strong enough in any one area and you may struggle, though that said it's not that hard a game. For example, I was told that my mage character could cast spells and use guns, but realistically to have a strong spell casting build for the end of the game, I couldn't afford to invest in gun skills. Like most RPGs, min/maxing is the key to success; pick a primary method of attack, boost your skills, increase your hitpoints and your dodge abilities and you will be fine. Having the ability to cast healing spells or taking mercenaries who have the healing spell is very, very useful.

For a game that is in large parts centred around dialogue, the dialogue choices seem kind of meaningless and selecting different options doesn't seem to change the outcome of the conversations or the way the game unfolds. You can spend karma (XP) points to gain new "etiquettes" which allow you to automatically pass a few speech checks in the game - opportunities to use these special etiquette skills appear very infrequently and some don't seem to appear at all. Unlocking all of the etiquettes is very expensive in terms of karma points and simply not worth it.

Likewise, the hacking skills seem very expensive and don't appear to be all that useful either. If you have no hacking skills, the game just assigns you an avatar provided to you by another in-game character, rather than forcing you to enter the virtual world and complete the hacking tasks yourself.

While I could criticise the game for it's slightly clunky feeling during gameplay or the way the RPG systems seem to present a world of choice while ultimately still being quite limited, it must be considered also that this is a cheap game, made a few years ago with a relatively small development team. For 15-20 hours of fun, I think it's worth playing if you like cyberpunk settings, isometric RPGs and noir detective stories, just don't expect anything that is going to change your life.

74983960.review:
Having played Shadowrun: Dragonfall and Hong Kong before this, I still found Shadowrun Returns to be a blast even though it lacks the scope and scale of the more recent games.

The combat is a lot of fun, giving you a variety of different weapons and strategies, from rifles and magic spells to robotic drones and summon spirits.

Shadowrun as a whole is one of the most immersive game series for me, and Shadowrun Returns does contribute to that. The world-building and lore are fascinating, and the game is completely soaked with atmosphere.

Still, the game feels a bit short and the missions should have given the player more freedom to solve problems with different options.

Other Shadowrun games would certainly have more freedom, content, and characterization. But for what it is, Shadowrun Returns was pretty enjoyable.

In short: definitely recommended for CRPG fans (and RPG players in general), though I more passionately recommend Dragonfall and Hong Kong.

74740683.review: The first of the modern Shadowruns, Shadowrun Returns is these days mostly a decent introduction to the franchise to anyone new to it, and interesting if short campaign for veterans. Shadowrun has long been plagued with the reputation of being conceptually fascinating with strong worldbuilding, but crippled by one of the clunkiest mechanics of any tabletop rpg; SR manages to avoid the latter problem while mostly retaining the strengths of the former. Dead Man's Switch, the campaign it comes with, is a fun toe-dip into the world, that regrettably kinda falls short in its finale where the cyberpunky grit sort of falls away in the face of a "we must save the world!" attempt at epic conclusion. It just feels tacked on, to tell you the truth. The real strength of SR is the near-limitless capacity for modding and campaign building in the steam workshop, where many interesting fan-builds are available (alongside an ocean of crap, to be honest), but these days better stuff can be found for either Shadowrun: Dragonfall, or Hong Kong (with the latter containing several needed technical improvements to game mechanics, magic and decking in particular). For all of that, SR is still worth having and playing.

74214102.review:
Shadowrun Returns is an abundantly stylish game; I want to see and experience more of this world and I even am considering buying the expansion campaigns. The central problem that I have with the game is that it is too short, though I do have a few gripes with your character stats. I enjoy short games and experiences, so let me explain.

The base campaign, Dead Man's Switch, felt like skim-reading an good novel. Most story characters you interact with only once, but are they written as if they have tremendous impact on the plot and main character. The story is like a murder mystery or police procedural, but I can't remember any discoveries you make that didn't feel like accidents. The primary obstacles seem inconsequential since they change or get overcome every mission. 

This brevity leads to some dissatisfaction with the game's mechanics as well. There appears to be only one optional mission, and it could have easily been added to the linear plot. The shopkeepers refresh their inventory precisely 3 times during the campaign, so the end-game gear feels only incrementally stronger than the starting setup. You hire party members for missions, but they all have mediocre stats marginally better than your starting class. And although the game seems generous enough when allowing you to upgrade your own stats, by the end of the campaign I didn't feel any kind of mastery in even my highest stat area. 

Speaking of my highest stat... Charisma is garbage in this game. In dialogue, it can occasionally give an alternate option which sometimes nets you a little extra money. However, charisma checks never allow you to unlock quest options that you couldn't get otherwise (either through another stat, money, or just... clicking to the next dialogue), and can be used to change someone's mind in an important way exactly once (to avoid a fight... if you happen to chose the right option during character creation, so it is not guaranteed). Now the developers were very clever and included some combat uses of charisma. However, these options are of little use in the best case, and have tremendous player-killing downsides in the worst case. The "good" abilities include a minor buff, a pitiful debuff, some extremely limited crowd control, and a spell called "Silence" which causes a character to not make any sound. The only problem with that last one is that this game does not feature stealth. I can recall a single mission in which you could sneak up behind an enemy... but doing so does not require "Silence"... and in every other instance enemies instantly see you. The ability with downside is summoning. Summoning either requires an expensive consumable item or for the tactical map to generously offer a location for summoning. When you summon a spirit, there is a random chance every turn for that spirit to irreversibly change from a party member to an enemy. Therefore putting points into charisma gives you the privilege to pay to make combat harder. Do not recommend.

I've tried three times over several years to play through this game, and I can never push through it. There's very little going on in the way of role-playing, the plot is thread-bare and gives the game away too soon in the first act (and [ACT 1 SPOILERS][spoiler]once the first act finally reaches it's conclusion, it's hell bent on demonizing the mentally ill, putting you in front of several neglected patients who you have no choice but to kill.[/spoiler]). 73734626.review:
This game is Cyberpunk (2020, Red, or 2077, what ever) with elves. I have played the tabletop version of the game, and was unimpressed really. But this is about the game.

I have never really been able to get into this game, or enjoy it. I feel like despite it advertising itself as an RPG, it railroads you pretty hard. It is more of a tactical turn based shooter like XCom or something, than it is a role-playing game. Character creation is fun, and at first it seems like there is so much that you will be able to do, so much diversity, so many different characters to make and experience the game in different ways through. This turns out to be an illusion. The etiquette system is pointless really, with almost no changes to the game as a whole. There are so many of them, as well as persuade, intimidate, etc etc. You would think that you could make a 'face' character focused on Charisma and charm and such, to talk your way through the game, but you can't. I can't emphasize more strongly that this is just wasting points.

You need guns, and you need spells. You really need spells. Playing a spell-caster makes this game easy mode. Playing anything other than a spell-caster, or a really powerful combat character will see your game ruined and you dead. The tech specialists in this game are disappointing, especially the ones who go into the matrix like computer realm. It is so pointless, it might have been removed completely from the game and no one would notice a difference. I could say more about this game, like the lack of compelling characters, or the boring music, or the fact that I don't really like the combat in this game (and it is mainly combat), etc, etc. Take it from a person who loves RPGs, both on the tabletop and in video games, this isn't very good. Then there are the bugs...

Don't get this game. If you really want to get this game, make sure you get it on sale. There are better games out there to spend your money on.

73693318.review:
I remember seeing this game on Kickstart!  I shared it on social media and hoped it wold get somewhere.  Eventually it was funded, developed and even landed on Steam!  However, I put off getting it.  Then they came out with the Deluxe Edition and I picked it up, and put off playing it.  Tonight I gave it a try!  Yes, I wanted those silly cards.  

The game has a lot of dialog.  It's an in depth storyline, based on the Shadowrun game of old.  Aside from the turned based action scenarios, the game lets you run around the map, and the dialog with many characters does slow down the game progression a bit, as it is a lot of reading and making selections on how your character responds.  The theme of the game is very much Shadowrun, and it looks visually amazing.  The gameplay itself feels like the original Fallout series.

I got this game added to Kick as a category.  See my clips on https://www.kick.com/ronjester

73658431.review:
Shadowrun Returns. I love the Shadowrun RPG, the good old Shadowrun, before Catalyst got their hands on it. So a Shadowrun video game was going to have an uphill battle against the power of nostalgia. And you know what? I enjoyed it. Solid B/B+.

Let's start by getting two things out the way: the interface is clunky and the plot is linear. But it has a solid plot told well, and maybe that's enough for you. It was for me. The story is a prequel to some notable events in Shadowrun's history, and it does a good job as threading the needle between "embrace the tropes" and "delight the audience with the unexpected." 

It won't dazzle you with graphics, the decking (hacking) sequences are a chore, you don't really get to make a lot of choices, and the controls/camera can be frustrating, but none of that really matters. I wish they were better, yes, but the FEEL of Shadowrun kept me coming back and looking to finish the story. It can be hard to nail down, but that sense of atmosphere is pretty important in a game, and Shadowrun Returns pulls it off. I look forward to Shadowrun Dragonfall and Shadorun Hong Kong.

73438535.review:
Shadowrun Returns is neither a particularly long nor deep game, but it's a well-written honest effort to provide PC gamers an accessible entry point into the world of Shadowrun.  For fans of the tabletop RPG first published in 1989 (raises hand) you'll find a classic rendition of one of the games's oldest and most beloved scenarios here. 

The gameplay is simplifed turn-based grid "X-COM lite" with a fun and straighforward decking (hacking) minigame.  Shadowrun's greatest strength was always in its writing & world building, and that's present in good quantity.  This is a game to be read and savored, as are its two sequels Dragonfall and Hong Kong.  If one finds oneself skipping text, it is advised to save the game and pick up when less tired and more amenable to reading comprehension.  Because the game is a bit threadbare here and there, you'll want to cooperate with its spirit to get the most out of it.  That's truly the only way to get full value from this game -- read it like the visual RPG novella that it's trying to be, and enjoy the set battles in between the narrative arcs.

Shadowrun's other major strength, character customization, is here in spades as well.  Though the RPG system is very simplified compared to the textbook-like qualities of the tabletop game, it allows the player to enjoy any or all the iconic archetypes of Shadowrun as their main PC.

See you in the shadows, chummer.

73221685.review:
Well well... the trilogy is finished. "But it's the first game!" - correct, and I played it last. And here's why you should too.

This is the order in which I played the games in:
1) SR Dragonfall Director's Cut (human decker)
2) SR Hong Kong Extended Edition (human street samurai / shaman)
3) SR Returns (elf decker)

And this is also my final ranking. Dragonfall being absolutely amazing, Hong Kong shortly lagging behind it due to overwhelming verbosity (which is great in the 2nd half, however a bit annoying in the beginning before you get invested in the story and the characters). And then we have Returns.

Shadowrun Returns is split in 2 acts. I would say the first act is actually great. The second half however visibly loses steam and devolves into a slightly underwhelming ending. This game is quite obviously a proof of concept, which had to pave the way for the following masterpiece.

For this reason I recommend playing it last - I enjoyed it very much, but chances are I wouldn't have played the whole trilogy had I started with Returns. Dragonfall, on the other hand, made me completely obsessed, so much I started Hong Kong on the very same day I finished it.

And now - I'm thinking of getting a SNES emulator to try the 1993 Shadowrun. Yeah, this whole thing got me good. Play it, chummer.

The game has a bug that locks up and leaves your character stuck during one of the key fights. This problem was reported in 2014, and to this day you'll still encounter it. Some people seem to be able to pass through that fight by retrying once and again until they get lucky... Ok, I would say that's a good temporary workaround if it still was 2014 and this issue was being fixed, but it's been 6 years already and it's clear that the devs won't do sh*t about it.

The game is pretty good and well in the style of RPG probability-based combat like XCOM. This should be a positive review, but everything gets out of the window the moment gameplay-breaking bugs like this are allowed to stay.

I took a really long time to install this game after receiving it. Maybe should have played it sooner, but I'm glad I finally did.

Without having any previous experience with the Shadowrun franchise, this game was pretty solid for an "outsider" like me. I didn't feel like missing information throughout the campaign that comes with the game. To my understanding you can play more created by other players, which could add a good bit of replayability. 
Turn based, linear game (which is not, by any means, something bad) with an engaging story and a extensively good amount of customization for the character you create (a lot of options for the shadowrunners you will seek to hire during your quests too). 

I write this review after finishing the campaign. It's very possible that you will finish the game sooner than me if you try to speed run it, but I prefer reading carefully every dialog and analyzing every possible response your character can say in said dialogs, options which will increase depending on your character stats. 

I'm now looking forward to playing the other Shadowrun game. Overall, just a pretty good game. I got it free, but I would recommend getting it if you can, specially on sales.

Too bad I missed this series when it came out. I recommend it if you enjoy X-com similar tactical turn based games; mostly for the stories. It's solid in gameplay as well.

I like the Shadowrun setting quite a bit, having read some of the fiction set in it, though I've never played any Shadowrun games prior to this, tabletop or vidya.

The story in this one is good, the characters are good, especially Coyote. Dodger was in this for a mission too, which is cool because he was in some fine fiction novels.

I think Dresden is a reference to the Dresden Files, which I approve of as that is a great series.

I recommend a Charisma based character. The etiquettes it unlocks are mostly useless, though one allows you at the very end to make what would be at least in some ways a slightly more sensible choice in dialogue.

The story has some elements of the best Shadowrun book I read in my opinion, which is the mystery-action book about Jack the Ripper, though that book was set in Britain. I cannot recall the author, my apologies, though it was a very well written book.

Shadowrun Returns is a cyberpunk-eske tactical RPG with a good story in which you have to discover who and why killed and old friend of yours.

I like tactical RPGs a lot and this is one of the nicest, I have to admit. There is a good variety of classes and you can choose the kind of combat that you want: melee, ranged, magic, summoning, with 'toys'... The pacing is good, and once you get the hang of it, you will enjoy it a lot.

72539749.review:
It doesn't much feel like Shadowrun. The official story is only about 5-10 hours, and anything after that is Workshop stuff which, from what I understand, is better to play on the sequels. The story is just a single, quick story. I doubt it has any bearing on the rest of the series. 

There are also many issues with the game that were never fixed. One big one is one particular area that you cannot pass if you're a rigger. You have to unequip all drones or the game will freeze. This is an area just before a lot of fighting so, if you maxed out on rigger stats, sorry! You do have a crew so it's possible to pass, but it's just stupid that such a blatant, game-breaking bug - which has been reported and talked about since release - has been around for over 6 years. I also noticed some crazy FPS drops, even though I'm running a 5700 XT with a Ryzen 5 2600. It would just sometimes slow to a crawl.

For what little there is to do, it's definitely not worth $15. If you can get it for a few bucks, it might be worth a play-through but, even then, it'll be largely forgettable. I doubt I remember much of anything about this game in a month or so.

72536299.review:
I know zilch about the Shadowrun table-top game, nor have I ever played the original SNES/Genesis title. I'm simply a CRPG junkie who was looking for a quick fix on a budget - and did this game ever deliver! It's brief (my first run took less than 18 hours), and only cost me about $4 on sale. In terms of bang-for-the-buck, Shadowrun Returns is great! Does it have the most exhaustive, complex turn-based combat system in the world? No. Is it the most polished game in the world? No. What it does offer is an entertaining, surprisingly ambitious narrative (with a number of satisfying plot twists), memorable characters and a reasonable degree of player agency within its linear framework. Class archetypes are all really cool, and the combat systems/mechanics provide juuuust enough depth and challenge to engage the player. 

If you're a fan of titles like OG Fallout, Wasteland 2, Divinity: Original Sin, Torment: Tides of Numenera, etc. but are looking for a leaner, 'breezier' experience, I can't recommend this game enough. Can't wait to start Dragonfall!

Resumen breve: Buen juego y buena historia. 

Para los amantes de las partidas de rol y los juegos por turnos. Los gráficos tienen su encanto y realmente la historia es buena por lo que resulta muy fácil jugarlo del tirón.

Pegas y gordas: La dificultad es baja, en modo normal no vas a morir ni una vez salvo que avances muy a lo bruto. No supone un reto, es casi mejor empezar en modo difícil, aunque si no haces las cosas bien y acumulas suficiente dinero en la parte final sudaras mucho. 
Otra pega, quizás la mas gorda. EL JUEGO DURA MUY POCO, y ¿Cuánto es poco? Pues unas 13 horas haciendo todas las misiones secundarias y leyendo casi todo detenidamente. Vamos que un suspiro. 

¿Re jugable?  NO, únicamente para hacerte el personaje hacker y jugar con esa dinámica, pero por lo demás… no vale la pena. Y quizás, solo quizás, volver a jugarlo con un personaje con etiquetas diferentes, por ver los cambios en los diálogos, aunque los sucesos en si no cambiaran prácticamente nada. Todo esto hablando de la campaña principal claro.

Luego si tienes buen nivel de inglés, y bueno no es el de andar por casa, puedes descargar en la workshop otras campañas hechas por fans.

Yo le daría un 7/10.  Si lo pillas en oferta, vale la pena pagar esos 3 o 4 euros.

We run in the shadows, it's what we do.

* Pros
+ Unique setting
+ Great character creator
+ Lots of build variety
+ Good story and characters
+ Retro wavy and cyberpunk soundtrack
+ Combat is decent
+ You get to have lots of interesting dialogue with a big cast of characters
+ Graphics and effects aren't anything special, but they work
+ Can be modded for user made campaigns

* Cons
- The UI seems like they designed it more for a tablet or phone rather then a PC
- Combat gets repetitive very quickly (Though when you unlock something new, it's fun to try it out)
- Characters don't get fleshed out enough
- The rigging (hacking) combat was pretty disappointing
- This game has so much potential, but the developers didn't give it that extra push it needed

Overall: 6/10 Above Average

70638050.review:
The short version: don't pay full price for this, it's not great and has little replayability.

I enjoyed my first playthrough enough to do another and that is when the game began to frustrate me immensely.  The story is compelling and involved, but the dialogue and outcomes don't seem to matter aside from trivial consequences that fail to affect the main plotline.

On my first playthrough, I played the game blind, using the flashback scene as a tutorial to discern basic functionality and navigation, on the hard difficulty setting.  For a novice to the game, this was not challenging.  Even while I played against type as a Troll Mage/Samurai hybrid and wasted karma, this difficulty was hardly "hard".  I didn't learn about the ability to reload guns until using the Aegis guns on the final mission; even without reloading guns and budgeting ammunition, this was quite an easy difficulty level.

On my second playthrough, with a better understanding of the Mage, Samurai, and Shaman classes, I built I hybrid Mage/Shaman to complete the "Very Hard" difficulty setting.  With the exception of the early game, prior to having access to the Seamstress Union to obtain the basic Mage weapon, this difficulty setting has been mostly a breeze.  

On "Very Hard", there are some really frustrating occurrances that occur in the Matrix, which seem to be a result of the higher difficulty setting and are inconsistent.  The enemies are accurrate to a much longer range and deal higher damage.  However, when using the Docker recommended later in the campaign for the break-in to get Aegis, this game-generated character is unable to land a majority of hits at point-blank range and it gets worse at longer ranges.

The game prides itself as a setting in which magic and technology merge, but casting the "Aim" spell on the Docker doesn't transfer into the Matrix; likewise for "Haste" to provide an additional action point (AP).  The second spell failing to affect is most concerning since the Docker itself has the same AP in the physical world as it does in the Matrix.  This seems to imply that a Docker needs greater proficiency to have more AP in the Matrix, but this implication is unsupported by the karma skill selection.  If AP in the Matrix is proficiency-based, I would expect a less experienced Docker to have less AP in the Matrix and a more experienced Docker to have more AP.  Unfortunately, the skills do not support this.


Other cons:
* How does a game with such minimal requirements take so long to load a save game or switch between scenes?
* There are shortcut keys, but the only way to know about them is through the tips in the loading screens; no in-game list or way to edit
* Dialogue options appear before the character learns of the information relevant to the dialogue option; e.g., Dresden having an option about the Seamstress Union before it's mentioned
* Unable to change equipment (armor, spells, weapons, etc.) of hired mercenaries
* Unable to browse items or spells while an action, such as casting a spell, is being performed
* Leylines are invisible outside of combat
* Spells cannot be used outside of combat; e.g., "Heal Wounds"
* Unable to loot enemies
* Main plotline doesn't change based on player decisions
* Inventory arrangement is randomly sorted on every load
* Unbalanced skill leveling; had 68 unspent karm left on "Very Hard" at end of game (could have easily been 100 if not testing dialogue options for outcomes)
* New characters do not start with equipment reflecting skillset: a classless character with all karma in Willpower and Spellcasting starts with a gun instead of Powerbolt
* Despite constantly returning to the Seamstress Union, some sellable quest items are removed from your inventory if you do not sell them immediately after returning to the Seamstress Union before departing again
* Group members can be targetted through portraits, but do not list effects on mouse-over unless casting
* Statistically improbable outcomes in Matrix: missing three times in a row with a 50% chance-to-hit is 12.5% and routinely occurs with chance-to-hit of 60-plus
* Statistically improbable miss rate on bug spirit forms in final level: missing five times in a row with a chance-to-hit of 70-plus for each character (two of seven shots hit); often, expect at least 30% to miss despite greater than 50% chance-to-hit metric displayed over enemy
* Not being able to traverse alleyways supported by art but not by engine
* Matrix enemies routinely attack from across the visible level with a success rate of about 30%; for "Dodger Persona", the chance-to-hit is below 50% and rate of success at this same distance is nill on three strikes in a row
* About 10% of the time, at the beginning of a round, the game decides the character you must use and you cannot select another character
* Avoiding the trap tile in the Matrix for the "Elevator Control Node" in Telestrian's office prevents access to the node until the trap tile is triggered
* All buffs are lost (reset) when leaving one area of a level to proceed to the next, but countdown timers and AP are still current; can't buff after clearing an area before proceeding to the next
* In the beginning, combat ends when all on-screen enemies are killed; later, combat does not function like this leading to using AP to navigate entire levels tediously

70171891.review:
I played more off record. After a few hours I really felt like it was my jam. Intriguing story, great worldbuilding and some decent characters. But the more I played and the more it fell into monotony. 

The game is very linear with little input from you. Almost everything has to be approached by fighting with no way of getting a strategy in place beforehand since you can only control your character outside of fights and there is little interactivity with the level unless you're playing a decker (eg. a hacker). All you do is walk into a room and get attacked instantly since the game gives the priority to the ennemy 2/3 of the time. Assembling a team before each run is cool on principle but you have so little intel before any run that you can't adapt to the mission.

The turn based gameplay was fine at the start but lacks depth, especially compared to the games that have come out since 2013. It's a cake walk most of the time until the game hits you with a nonsenical difficulty spike or 6 75% shots missing in a row leading you to die in a stupid way. I know about dice roll mechanisms. I've played pen and paper RPG, Darkest Dungeon and XCOM, so I'm familiar with bad luck, but the combat in Shadowrun Returns isn't engaging enough to make me want to start the fight again from the beginning.

I couldn't bring myself to finish this one, especially because the story didn't keep me interested all the way. I'll definitely try Dragonfall though since the developpers seem to have improved a lot of things in the sequels.

69972482.review:
IF you like the type of games I positively review, this one isn't for you. I'm not saying there is something wrong with it for people who are into it, but this review is for the folks that need to know what they're getting into.j

If you want a very cyberpunk plot, cheese included, this is right up your alley. You have to be deep into the writing style prominent in the genre in order to stomach the game. For me, it was too corny. I couldn't get into the writing.

If you're into visuals/aesthetics, this will put you into the story faster than anything about the game. They have it pegged.

Gameplay is the thorn in the series side. It's click and point moving, and turn based fighting. For someone who wants to be immersed, waiting your turn to hit your opponent is a deal breaker. If you want a game you can play at a crawling and waiting pace, this is the game for you. If you are super into games that require knowledge of mechanics alone with no technical skill, this is a great pick. Kind of like some of the older Final Fantasy games.(lots of knowledge, not a lot of skill) If you need to be able to add some sort of skill to the game to enjoy it, this isn't the game for you.

For me, it's a hard pass. I'm a moving parts type. The games that catch me best are the ones where I can really make my way freely around the map. The more fluid the movement in a game the better.

For those who liked the rest of the series, this one will do you fine until you find your next obsession.  I tend to do the same with games. Pick up the original, love it, then feed off sequels until I find something new to jump into. Unfortunately, this series is not the something new I thought it could be for me.

69322206.review:
Not the best of the three. Not the worst of the three. I played Dragonfall first (which was fantastic), then Hong Kong (which was very okay but too long), and only recently played through this game, which is chronologically the first in the series. It does a good job of introducing the Shadowrun world to new players, and has a couple of cool references to the source material for Shadowrun fans.

I quite like that the game's scale is much smaller. Rather than a group of criminals trying to save the world, in Returns, you're just one runner who hires help chasing down leads in one job. Its playtime is also much shorter then: 12-14 hours instead of the 40+ on both Dragonfall and Hong Kong. 

Going back in time to play the first game last, I was a bit reluctant but eventually surprised in how well it managed to hook me again. Though, of course, the same for the others applies: the UI is frustrating (mild improvement in later games), Matrix combat is tedious, and in general it could use a little more spectacle in the animations and effects. 

That said, definitely worth a playthrough, either as run-up to Dragonfall or if you want a shorter Shadowrun game.

68947571.review:
Overall, a very pleasant experience.  Makes one feel like they are actually seeing the imagining of the table-top version, as well as an update to the SNES game from the 90s.  Bought this, and the other two Shadowrun titles on sale about a year ago.  I only regret not starting to play them sooner.  

PROS:  Fun, in-depth story.  Simple enough to start, but in-depth enough to allow number crunchers to have a hay-day.  Grid-based combat that actually makes your decisions have weight.  Definite replay value.

CONS:  Only one story, "Dead Man's Switch."  Don't get me wrong, "Dead Man's Switch," was awesome, I just wish there were more stories to check out (because it was THAT damn fun). Solid turn-based isometric RPG effort.  It has excellent art design, good overall writing, and the combat is mostly fun.

68082525.review:
My first and favorite of the three Shadowrun games. For one reason, THE STORY. "Shadowrun Returns" gives you a classic tabletop "Who done it?" murder mystery premise, while at the same time giving you the unique sense that your character (The one you just made up 2 minutes ago), and their motivations are completely personal, real, and justified through it's amazing writing and dialogue selection. The other Shadowrun stories are good, but never captured this flavor, falling into the trap of more traditional Bioware style RPG's. 

One of my favorite deviations from the typical RPG mechanic, is that there is NO PARTY of companions at a home base where you can regularly drop in for backstory as you level up. Companions come in and out of your characters story, in a realistic way depending on the choices you make. They seemingly have lives to live, and don't simply want to hang around in the same spot for the entirety of the game waiting for you to take them into combat. You are a lone Shadowrunner, making your way through the gritty city. Sometimes you make friends you can call on, most of the time you hire mercenaries when you think you'll need it, and sometimes people hire you, which fits perfectly into the Shadowrun world. Instead of stay at home companions, you have a fully realized cast of NPC's throughout the city, that have rich histories that you can and probably will want to find out more about. 

Gameplay is linear, but my god is it clean. This is a throwback to a time when you didn't have a million fetch quests, and a trillion collectables, where every townsperson has a sidequest and audio recordings to look over, and an open world so huge you have to quit your day job to get from one side of the map to the other. You have a singular mission, and sometimes you have an incident or two that is so involving and you get so invested in that you have to stop what you're doing and help that person out (Or not), but then you immediately get back to the meat of the game. This creates a cohesive momentum to the game I haven't seen in a long time. 

Combat is simple, and the UI is far from perfect. Decking in particular leaves a lot to be desired especially after having played the other Shadowrun games, but it is entertaining enough to get you through to the next best parts of the game, and mostly true to the tabletop version. 

Loved it, wish there were more like it.

67609987.review:
This is a great isometric CRPG set in the dystopian cyberpunk future world setting of Shadowrun, which is one of my favorite tabletop RPG systems. They especially did a great job balancing out turns between those in combat and your decker(s) in the Matrix, which was always a hard balancing act when playing the TTRPG. I'm also a big fan of the Shadowrun setting and lore, and there were definitely many nods in the game to lore that was established in the novels, even including a few characters like Harlequin and James Telestrian III. (Which, as a side note, the novels are all available in ebook format again now that the long-standing rights issues were cleared up.) Add on to that the fact that you can also create user generated content (from things like avatars to a full fledged story campaign), and you're looking at basically the Shadowrun equivalent of D&D 3E's Neverwinter Nights. I fully enjoyed the campaign (although I loathe bug shaman *shudder*), and I'm looking forward to sinking my teeth into Dragonfall next.

I originally backed this on Kickstarter (and then the same with Dragonfall and Hong Kong), and I don't know why I hadn't finished this before now. Originally, I spent some time playing Dead Man's Switch on my Android tablet, but unfortunately HBS recently removed it (along with Dragonfall; as far as I know, Hong Kong was never ported to Android) from the Google Play Store to avoid having to make changes to comply with GDPR. (Which doesn't make sense to me, but that's what their support folks told me.) So PC is pretty much the only option to play it at this point. I'll also note that it does work with Macs running an OS version predating OSX Catalina (I played this primarily on a Macbook using OSX Mojave); Apple dropped support for 32-bit apps in Catalina, and all three games in this trilogy are. Given what occurred with GDPR, I would very much not expect them to be updated to 64-bit apps to work under Catalina and future OSX releases.

66792873.review:
I give it a 4/10, and wouldn't recommend the game for most people. Only buy it if you're a fan of CRPGs and you can find it on sale for dirt cheap. 

Cons:

VERY short - Sub 10 hours. Possibly fixed with user generated campaigns however I haven't tried any of these, and all of the big ones I looked at were unfinished. My play time is a result of AFKing for about 7 hours. 

Buggy - At least two main story missions have well known bugs where the only solution is reloading a save. That may not sound like much but it's a very short game.

Linear - Only 1 side quest and most of the "optional objectives" are as straight forward as "pick up this impossible to miss item in the next room". Sometimes you have multiple choices, however there are rarely consequences for anything you choose. You get a large choice at the end of the game but as far as I can tell, it only changes flavor. Even choices like race rarely come into play. There's a mission where you have to infiltrate a base, and it's one of the only non-linear sections of the game but few options are locked out based on your race and class. Want to disguise yourself as a janitor? Okay, there's conveniently a janitor outfit for every race in the lockers. Didn't invest in hacking skills but want to make a fake ID? Just memorize some names instead of hacking. Why bother giving me a choice if all options are open to me regardless?

Pacing - What the heck is up with the pacing? It feels like they intended to have a lot more plot development that was cut in the final product. As an example, you rescue a character that becomes a semi-regular companion early on in the game, and despite it clearly being explained that you've never met this person before you saved them, she's talking like she knows you in the next encounter with her. I feel like there was going to be a side quest or something with her that would build up that friendship, but it's not there.

Mixed:

Character portraits - they're usually fine but hipster orcs and metrosexual trolls are a little bit jarring.

Pros:

Gameplay - no major issues, skills work as you would expect. My only complaint with this is how easy many bullshit misses there are. If I have a 99% chance to hit, I would expect to hit my target at a higher rate than 9/10, whereas 99% seems more like 7/10. Below 50% and you're better off just not bothering. Otherwise it's fine. Nothing to write home about but if you like turn based, somewhat tactical CRPG combat with light investigation elements you will probably enjoy this.

Visuals - Fine, most things look nice.

Story - Despite the aforementioned linearity and pacing issues, the story is quite nice. It starts out as a cyberpunk noir where you investigate a murder, before eventually a larger, lovecraftian conspiracy unfolds. It REALLY needed a few missions to pad this out and let the larger mystery unfold slowly, but overall I liked it.


Overall its a neat little crpg but it feels more like a high quality mod than a full game.

66463979.review:
I didn't know much about Shadowrun...

I had friends that played the table top and would often recall fun adventures and stories about events that unfolded. 

Somewhere in this universe, there exists an Augmented, Ex-Mafia, human, bomb-maker. Who, as a fail-safe, must always be whistling 'Hey Jude' on his way up the stairs to his own condo. Any potential trespasser, not knowing this, will find themselves trapped inside a concrete-isolated small apartment. Strobe lights will be deployed, dub-step will start playing and after 20 seconds C4 charges will blow. -A man also known for throwing a backpack full of bootleg Semtex and ball bearings at a dragon.


Anyway, I digress:
Shadowrun Returns was my personal introduction into the world of Shadowrun, It was, and is amazing.

Please first understand; gameplay mechanics are simplistic:
talk/explore/trade with turn-based combat.

However,  The mini exploration and combat is just the vehicle to take you through this amazing story. It's a comfortable ride. 

The main campaign "Dead Man's Switch" was absolutely gripping, with plenty of dialogue options and multiple paths to lead your team. Additionally, custom made campaign's can be downloaded from Steam Workshop, some of them are phenomenal.

Please don't let the basic gameplay dissuade you.

[b]- Some top-level Story Craft. 9/10 [/b]

66452864.review:
[h1]Shadowrun Returns[/h1]

This is a turn-based RPG. We start by creating our own character. The creator himself is quite poor, but I think he's quite satisfying. Then we start our adventure in a fantastic world. We can develop many skills. The tree of skills is very disintegrated and interesting. The game is linear, we will not experience the openness of the world here, but the plot is really addictive and interesting. While playing, I noticed that there are more dialogues in the game than just playing, shooting and moving around the map.

[h1]Graphics and sound[/h1]

The game looks nice. The textures are pretty good. All the animations are decent. There is no rotating the camera around here, so all we can do is zoom in or out. The music is very good and addictive. It's a pity the dialogues aren't read and we can only read them and not listen to them.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

Although I'm not a fan of this kind of games, I can consider Shadowrun Returns a successful title. The game is addictive, although its linearity is an element that rejects me. Great dialogues and music make the game good, but I can't say that it's a top-notch game. I strongly recommend to all fans of Shadowrun Returns-like games, but I think it's a game that someone won't like for too many dialogues.
[b]
✔️Soundtrack
✔️The plot of the game
✔️Dialogues
✔️Advanced skills system

✔️❌Graphics

❌Short
❌No open world and few side tasks

[b][u]Rating: 7/10[/u][/b]

66441664.review:
Pros-


Perfect story elements along

Being able to make your character whatever you want. There are 8 or so different classes and you can spec into however many you want. I went into rifles and long range magic and it was awesome for my first run.

Satisfying combat with a good save system considering bugs (see below)

Story was great and you can tell, 100%, that your choices in words matter.

Everything else

Cons- 

I wish there were more sidequests and ways to make money. A couple times I got a mission and only had enough money to hire 1 other person (was getting girl free at the time) to go with and it made the mission reeeeeeally hard. Keep that in mind while playing.

Graphics are a bit dated but if you play zoomed out as much as I did you don't notice. Besides some rooms staying black and the contents of the room taking a couple seconds to load. Old machines should be able to run this game well though.

Had a couple bugs (this is where the save game feature kept me from never touching this game again).
I had a mission I had 2 game breaking bugs in which I had to load a previous save and figure it out. 

A girl was hacking a machine, at first kept freezing at my turn. Couldn't figure it out after multiple boots and integrity checking. Then, randomly, it gave me my turn. Turns out it wasn't loading the other NPC as a playable character to hack a computer and freezing instead. Then it randomly worked. AFTER THAT. I beat the mission, just had to run out the door, and when it was that NPC's turn she wouldn't walk any where. After about an hour of reloading and trying different stuff I actually died in the computer while hacking (was kind of like "omg this fucking sucks I'm about to fucking drop this game" and ran in without summoning my partner and died) after I died I was able to MOVE my NPC then rehack and IT WORKED! 

Haven't had any other issues and I love the game still. Even though it gave me 2 hours of the most frustrated I've been trying to solve a video game problem.

Wel-come to the shadows, chummer. You want money? Power? In the shadows you see t'ose t'ings a plen'y. Oh, t'ey will come and go. You will see highs, ne'er dreamed, before re-turning to de slums. Who gives a drek, 'bout-at? You are free. 

This game is a good introduction the table top RPG universe of Shadowrun, where you play a shadowrunner. A person who lives in a walls of the establishment. Shadowrunners exist outside the norms of society, and find employment doing things for people with power and money. People that can find a use for a person who doesn't identify to any master or corps. A person who can't be identified, at all, if you do things right. It can be lucrative. It often is. The game itself is mechanically sound. I never have glitches or problems. The stories are sound and you can DL player made adventures, which makes it easy to keep playing this for a long time.

65434734.review:
LIST OF ISSUES
mods ,and extra stories, don't seem to work (this biggest issue)

only 1 story (well written though)

Not  an open world. 

Lots of scenery but can't interact with anything much.

can't loot bodies.

can't sell stuff. 

limited inventory and store options . This is Shadowrun! You should be able to upgrade the drek out of any weapon. Why can't i buy a laser sight, scope, suppressor?  Why can't i use poisons? Sleeping gas? Use drugs on people? 

Body modifications give very low bonuses, not worth the money. 

can't know what mission requires before hiring team.

can't hire team without being on mission. 

can't buy supplies for team after hiring and before starting mission. (WHY?)

Skill tree don't matter much - you'll use some skills like Charisma (gang/adcademics/socialite) three times at the most for each and you can easily go without. 

Conversation options rarely matter if not getting you more money out of a deal which seeing the very limited shop inventory is kinda pointless. 
============================
The saddest point in all of this is that there is no need to play this game outside the following configuration:

Rigger with lots of points into dodge and rest into whatever (doesn't matter much -maybe basic decker )
Get team members that can cast Haste on you and dakka your way out of a situation. 
Use drone to scout, AI will mostly target your drone first then just neutralize everybody while they are distracted. 

I tried to replay a second time but winded up with making , more or less, the same runner i did on my first playthrough. What is the point of replaying if everything is the same?

This game had so much potential. 
====================================================

I got it on special. So I didn't pay anywhere near full price (ergo, not so pissed). If you're new to Shadowrun this is ok. But if you are not... prepare to be very disappointed.

64827812.review:
I'm not much a Tabletop/Pen & Paper kinda guy. Mainly out of a lack of patience. Going into this I was worried it was going to be 'RPG elements and then some'. Quite the opposite, actually. The game's moderately complex when it comes to the RPG mechanics but keeps almost all of it simple to understand and explains everything you need to know.

And that's impressive, because you've got some serious freedom in how you build your character. The game frequently reminds you to make a decision sooner rather than later as to where you want your build to go. I went with Assault Rifle primarily and dipped lightly into Wisdom (for an extra spell slot and to facilitate a buff + healing spell) and some Charisma (for etiquette-specific speech checks) and there was very little I couldn't handle, which is where my team fits in.

I want to pre-emptively tackle decking. Decking is awesome. I got a little bit of a taste in it but felt that all in all the opportunities had more potential than proper execution. This is something that's addressed quite well in Dragonfall, but that's for another review.

For a tabletop universe that's returned from the shadows (pun not intended, or maybe a little bit) to tackle the gaming scene again, there's a lot of minor gripes that are forgiveable that have, again, been largely addressed in Dragonfall. Despite there being no voiceovers, there's a lot of personality to the characters you run into, but they're not unforgettable. Coyote stood out the most, but even she wasn't much of a character in the long run, and the Harlequin character that joins you right for the last mission is stuffed with personality but only has the length of one mission to really shine. That's too short. Again, however, Dragonfall addresses this.

Shadowrun Returns isn't awfully long, but it's a good test whether this style of RPG is up your alley. If it is, I'd not only heartily recommend Shadowrun Dragonfall, but I'd also prompt you to give Divinity: Original Sin 2 a try. I feel that, in terms of mechanical atmosphere, both games have a lot in common. 

Finishing this urged me to give Dragonfall a shot, the completion of which subsequently has inspired me to look out for the next time Shadowrun: Hong Kong is only sale, no matter how shallow a sale it might be. I'm sold, I'm down, I want more of this.

Ultimately, I can only summarize this review by saying that Shadowrun is a type of RPG that we don't have many of, and you should definitely give a try to see where you stand on it.

Shadowrun Returns is a fun little Turn-Based RPG with a beautiful Cyberpunk atmosphere. The game has a well-written story, with plenty of dialogue choices. The characters are all likable. The inclusion of the Shadowrun Editor gives you the ability to enable a New Game+ mode, which is nice, since you can't unlock very much of your in-depth skill tree with only one run with the game. 

The only downside for Shadowrun Returns is in how short and linear it is. The game can probably be beaten in 15 hours or less, although, it took me about 20 hours because I read everything in the game and reloaded my saves to choose different dialogue choices. 63750686.review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#161 out of 555)... it's time Shadowrun Returns(: Dead Man's Switch).

Dead Man's Switch is the first and weakest entry in Hairbrained Schemes' Shadowrun CRPG trilogy. It's relatively linear and there's not much narrative reactivity compared to the later entries. Still, it's an engaging campaign and does an excellent job introducing (or reintroducing) Shadowrun's cyberpunk setting. The writing is generally very good, the characters memorable, and the combat engaging. More importantly the themes are on-point and the presentation perfectly evokes that "Shadowrun" feel better than any of the prior attempts. And, of course, there's the enormous appeal of user-created modules, of which there are many, some of which are genuinely excellent.

I've seen some people advise skipping the first game, because Dragonfall--and, later, Hong Kong--are such big improvements. And while I agree that the latter two entries in the trilogy are significantly better, I would still recommend playing Dead Man's Switch. It's a solid adventure, and if nothing else will whet your appetite for the other games' full-course meals in the future

Note: also played on mobile.

Sure you start out with pre-made templates for specific classes but you can really customize your characters to do anything. Some races however, are better at some skills than others. Humans are boring as usual. Elves are pretty looking and have honeyed words, and trolls are good at hitting people with sticks.  The story is your average cyberpunk drama filled with intrigue, and mystery. it's a by-the-numbers RPG story. but it's good, You'll enjoy it if you like tactical RPG's. it's a shame its Hong Kong sequel was garbage, so we probably wont be getting any more of these.

63412762.review:
Simple tactical game with a linear plot. Very story driven game that starts with you attempting to find the killer of your best friend. It is set in seattle in the future with a very grunge mystical steampunk vibe where the world is ruled by corps. There are elves, humans, trolls, orcs, dwarves which are all playable races. There was some tension between races but I dont feel like the game got into that nor did it necessarily need to. There were a bunch of classes you can choose from like samurai, mage, shaman, rigger, decker, etc. RIgger and Decker are cool since Decker allows you to "hack" into computers and enter a virtual world and is relevant in the plot although you always have one at your disposal when the story counts on it. You get whisked into a plot that is half noir half fantasy. I was actually enthralled with the story the whole way through. It’s a short game (8-10hrs) but they did a fantastic job giving the characters dimension and some dynamic change. I didn’t feel all that attached to the characters or my own character for that matter but i generally really enjoyed the story and felt like the characters were real. 

The world building was also fantastic. They did a good job of showing the daily struggle people face, the dark sides of society and capitalism. You are essentially a mercenary that runs heists. It didn’t feel all that Seattle but I got some vibes from it here and there, but mostly with the journal like entries when you’re loading into a new zone. I think the Im a tad biased since Im from seattle and have a better picture of it in my head than the game had. The environments were a little boring at times and kinda felt all the same at the end. They did always try to set the scene well, but that’s hard to remember when you are just seeing the some corporate and dingy areas all the time. I’d like to see more diversity there. 

Music is great but I like future synth. It’s a bit overdone in games now but they did a solid job of it adding to the game’s theme. Sometimes it was a bit repetitive 

The combat was turn based 4x game. I like all the various classes and weapons choice but they don't seem to do things all that differently. I was an elf samurai with max quickness and nearly max pistol. You can diversify slightly but you do mostly have to stick with one track if you want to be formidable in combat. Combat can get challenging at time but for the most part was very manageable on normal difficulty. I’d like to see more diverse weapon systems and magic systems but i also didnt explore it as much as I should have. The armor was also pretty boring and I dont think they did as much with the cybernetics as they could have. 

There were alternate dialogue choices based on what “etiquette” you have which added some fun variation but overall I dont think it impacted the story much, which is good or bad depending on preference I suppose. I think this game excels with the plot so I’m fine with it not diverging much and just having the dialogue choices add a bit of flavor to interactions here or there. 

Overall, fricken solid strategy game with a great plot to back it up. I’d like to see an improved weapons and armor system, but I think for what this game is going for it did it really well.

62488499.review:
Wiz, chum, lemme chip ya some know-how on this thing called "Shadowrun."  So, like, in the late 20th century around the time of Talking Heads and Madonna there was this game kids played with pencils, paper, dice, rulebooks, and a whole lot of imagination. The game was set in the 2050's or some such, which back then felt like it would never come. So like, another game that was way more popular because it was the "granddaddy" of this hobby called Dungeons & Dragons, or D&D, was pretty cool and all. You had elves, and dwarves, and large metal pointy sticks to stab at things with, and magic! And there was another lesser known game Traveller that had spaceships and mutants and laser guns and aliens and stuff. Then like these dudes at FASA were like, "Whoah, lets put peanut butter in with the chocolate and stuff and make Fantasy Sci-Fi" and so they make a really amazing backstory based on the earth of the 1980's and extrapolated out about 70 years into the future adding in lots of future technology, magic, and even explaining why there are elves and dwarves and even dragons when we don't have those today (as far as we know).  SHADOWRUN was born and it was mega wiz, chummers.

So fast forward a bit to 2008(?) ish and while several good console and computer Shadowrun games had been made it had been a long time since any good ones and so Hairbrained Schemes did a Kickstarter to fund Shadowrun RETURNS, an all new SR engine for making SR stories, and of course, it came with a 20+ hour adventure, Dead Man's Switch, which was a little rusty at launch but is really solid as of this writing.

This is essentially a turn-based, tactical team-based RPG where you control one main character that has a lot of NPC's and hired hands to fill out a team of Shadowrunners, folks who get paid on the down-low to do illegal and very probably immoral jobs, with much discretion, for large sums of Nuyen (cash). The Dead Man Switch story is set in Seattle and an ex-Seattle runner RETURNS to Seattle to solve the murder of one of his old running chummers.  The first mmm 2/3 ish of the story is about solving his murder and a series of serial killings, while making friends and influencing people and gaining personal wealth and power. The next part diverges into a "save the world" kind of story kind of based on some of the stuff from the first part but that's when it gets kind of weird, but still fun and cool. I feel like the first part of Dead Man's Switch that is about solving the mystery of Sam's murder is great, and then the part near the end where you solve the big crisis is just pretty good but since it didn't feel very natural (in many ways, hehe, no spoiler) it almost felt like they needed more foreshadow during the mystery part about the ending in some way where maybe you encounter just little teasers of the "weird stuff" before the big all-out shindig.

All in all, this is a strong recommend A+ and one of the most satisfying RPG games I've played on any platform, and I've played literally dozens of them on many platforms going back to the Atari 2600. I would not rank it quite as high as Dragon Age Origins which I still think is my favorite PC RPG of all time, but it's in the same league as that, Fallout, Planescape Torment, Baldur's Gate, etc.
