60898891.review:
Didn't have any previous knowledge of the Shadowrun universe (although I do like cyberpunk games as a whole) but I still found this to be pretty enjoyable.

The primary campaign of this game has you investigating the murder of one of your old partners in crime, with the promise of a 100,000 nuyen payday. This promise leads you on a chase across the decaying metropolis of Seattle, and deep into a rabbit role of conspiracies. It's classic strategy RPG fun, although I did notice a few issues:

- The campaign is pretty short can be beaten in like 10 or so hours.

- The game is pretty easy compared to the sequel I played (Dragonfall), even on Hard difficulty. You are given loads of experience to pump up your stats.

- There's very little in terms of greater map exploration and side-content, you're more or less ferried along from story mission to story mission.

- Some of the skills (such as the Charisma Etiquettes) are severely underused.

The ending also gets a little wacky, but I still found the final missions to be pretty enjoyable despite the weirdness. If you like scifi, magic, and strategy RPGs, I'd pick this one up when it's on sale.

59878915.review:
Shadowrun Returns gives a perfect simulation of the Shadowrun tabletop experience: pretty, well statted, and completely devoid of depth.

The characters explain their motivations in monologues, rather than in depth conversations. Many conversational options lead to the same responses. Representation is treated *extraordinarily* shitty, outright stating people's race instead of allowing it to become evident, and relying on some very old tropes for their characters. Certain characters are written tolerably- Dan the Donut Man comes to mind- but others are atrocious. Nearly every man you meet is a smirking edgelord who drinks and lives life on the edge, as well as many of the women. It's an abysmal representation of humanity, falling into the folly of many, MANY cyberpunk stories before it.

Worse than poorly written- in every sense of the word, I'd die of alcohol poisoning if I played count the typos- the story is outright boring. Most NPCs push you in the same direction in their conversation, repeating the same things over and over again. It makes me wish that this RPG lacked choices and had reduced content- what the fuck is the point of letting me talk to nine people if they all say they say something similar? You could tell this story with half of the characters that it has, and it wouldn't lose anything.

The combat is very good, however. 2/5, play it once if you buy it on sale or get it as a gift.

59374108.review:
Shadowrun Returns is a mix of RPG with Turn based combat. The RPG aspect of the game is very complex, you got all sorts of skills to level up, magical: like spirit control, chi, conjuring, spell casting; combat: like melee, dodge, shotgun, machine gun, strength. decker type and/or drone control like. Depending what path you choose you could master one of the five or four classes that the game has, Shaman, Mage, Decker (hacker), Drone Expert, Samurai, (and there are few more). Then if you want, you could refine that even more you could create a Mage that's has expertise in ranged weapons (for example), or a Decker (hacker) that it's also a Shaman. Also you got other skills (none combat based) that are important for interacting with elements and talking with NPCs... Shadowrun, Decking, Socialite, Corporate, etc. Those skills are very important in some levels it makes the mission a lot easier. Sometimes with those speaking/hacking skills you could make an enemy surrender, make a smart computer open a locked door or make an enemy leave the battlefield instead of having to kill it.
 
Apart from your character which can be any class of the ones mentioned, (shaman, mage, etc). Also it can be an Orc, Elf, Human, Dwarf, etc. This also have some impact on the skills tree, some races have more resistance to melee combat and other are more skilled in magical aspects. So a character can be very complex.

In the first missions you are alone but as the game progresses you have to assemble a crew. A good hint is always to have a decker, hence some missions can't be even be completed without it. ( In other versions of the series some mission require a drone expert).  Most of the mercenaries (shadowrunners) cost money some of them are free but just 1 or 2. I normally carry a Decker, a Samurai or combat expert and another Mage or Shaman. Some ppl play different styles because there is plenty of possibilities on how to finish the mission, that heavily depends on your skills and also on your crew. 

I chose being an Elf Mage, with Mages you can summon spirits that are like dummy warriors that have a limited lifespan. And Elfs have better bonus points in spirit control and spirit summoning.  
On my crew I like having another mage/shaman also that can summon spirits makes combat really easy because instead of having 4 characters on the battle you have 6, it's a killer advantage. But there is catch summoned spirits spells and other casts are really expensive, (at least the ones that are powerful), so you have to do some side missions to earn enough money to be able to buy enough magic weapons/spells. 
You might choose another path for example when I played SR Hong Kong (the first of the series I played) I chose combat samurai. Maybe that's what you should choose if you are a newbie to the series, imho is much more simpler only reload the weapon, take cover and fire.... but remember to supply yourself with a LOT of medical supplies (maybe you could carry a powerful Mage/Shaman that has healing capabilites also). 

At the start you will find yourself dying a lot, the game is not that difficult but yes it's rather complex. I really didn't fully understood everything till I finished SR Hong Kong (which was the first I played). But once you master it if you like RPG/Strategy games it's very satisfying.
Then there is the story. Prepare yourself to read a lot. It's an important part of the game sometimes NPC's will give you hints to earn cash or acquire items. The first time I played the Hong Kong version I practically skipped every dialogue because it can be really tiresome. That made the game a lot more difficult, because I was short of cash. But  anyways if you are the kind of ppl that don't like reading you can skip most of it, it is doable.

Overall I think is a superb game with lots of depths and complexity, I think that maybe some day I will play it again. Also there's quite a lot of replayability  because depending on the character class you choose the game is different also what character classes you carry on your crew changes the game. But the enemy AI in the combats will mostly do the same thing there also a lot of scripted combats and environments ... so it has replayability but to some extent. 

the only issue I found is like many games it doesn't disable compositing so if you have a screen edge set up to trigger a desktop effect it can bother sometimes.

Played on KDE Neon 5.17.3 (Ubuntu 18.04 based). Mesa-dev 20.0 ACO valve drivers. 
CPU Ryzen 2600. RAM 8GB, GPU Radeon Rx 570.

59322797.review:
If you are chomping at the bit for cyberpunk and don't wanna wait for 2077 then this is the game for you. As a fan of the SNES version back in the day, I can say that Harebrained Schemes know how to tickle at my nostalgia while adding a XCom-like combat system and expressive dialogue to boot. 

This game's atmosphere and lore can be summarized by imagining a Tolkien fantasy world where the technology of the future evolves with the various races of Elves, Trolls, Humans, and Orcs. The setting is magic vs machines, tomes vs tech and that's still a very untapped genre (Shitty Netflix "Bright" Movie notwithstanding).

The Good: Setting, characters, customization, and player expression. The soundtrack ain't bad, either- particularly the opening theme. 

The Bad: Story is far more linear than I care for, and the environments- while pretty- aren't interactive. So, don't expect every beautifully designed area to yield loot or reward for being curious. 

The Ugly: If you hate reading, then stay away. This game is text heavy- far more than most modern RPGs. The indie budget of this game shows in more than a few spelling errors (not a huge knock, 'cause I'm not a perfect writer either- see above); this offering has to stand next to big boy RPGs that have voice acting and AAA funding. 

Overall: Bring your imagination, and an open mind. They don't make them like this anymore.

The candle that burns twice and bright, lasts half as long.

57441842.review:
I cannot recommend "Shadowrun Returns". There are many reasons, but let's stick to the main ones:

[b]Non-interactive environments.[/b] Almost nothing on the map can be interacted with. I can forgive dated looks, it's content, not glitz, that matters. But where is the content, I ask? Exploring maps will yield maybe one side mission, one extra thing to sell, etc. That's it. Exploring every nook and cranny is hardly worth it and largely unrewarding. Almost no enemy leaves loot behind or a body to search - except for a few key clues and items.

[b]It's a railroad![/b] Enter an area, beat the main thing in it, go to next area. You have no choice where to go. You rarely have a choice about anything! You can occasionally do a side mission or obtain an extra thing, but the game funnels you through a series of areas that could be seen as individual missions. No open world, no choices. The game would have been a great platform for making your own runs, given that an isometric game like this makes asset reuse and new maps cheap. But so far the game's decision graph is pretty much entirely linear.

[b]Does it matter what I say?[/b] While you get to chose the tone of the conversation, you rarely actually get to chose what to say. And I don't think the tone will matter often if at all. Be snide or be nice or be uncaring. That's flavor, but what else? I get a distinct vibe that dialogue options all lead to the same outcome. They are pseudo-choices.

[b]Missing info.[/b] What skill do I use with what gun? Couldn't find it. What does the Suppression program do - what is an "alarm level?" Missing bits of into are everywhere. The game does not explain itself very well.

[b]This is not Shadowrun.[/b] Shadowrun is a game about carefully planned and executed runs. Often planning a run takes as long as executing it. Intel is key. Timing and work split are of the essence. What remains in Shadowrun Returns? You often blunder into a scene (and this is supposed to be a "run") with no intel, you fight two combats, then pick up everything. Normally drone operators and deckers would provide you with enough information to do your job and apply force only when necessary. You strike when necessary or get out without even leaving a trace. That's the Shadowrun ideal. 

What does this game do? You rush in, bump into the enemy, then shoot your way through. D&D with guns and cyberdecks.

[b]No party.[/b] At least no party you can control. People join you and abandon you without you having any choice over it. You only get to build one character. You better make the character decent in combat because you cannot rely on being complemented by others. I built a decker but then optimized her for firefights. Because that's. All. That. Ever. Happened. For quite a while. Later on decking becomes important, too. And you get to hire runners for individual jobs which allows you to plan a little, but with little intel it's a way to trade money for a party to match your style (more magic or more firepower or whatever). 

You can also equip people from your stash. So putting stuff in there can be helpful in the early game when you get companions with no choice as to who they are. Can at least buff them somewhat.

[b]Conclusion.[/b] The game tells an interesting story that immerses you into the world of Shadowrun. It rarely explains much of the background info but you can ask about key concepts. Interaction with the world is oversimplified. This is neither a game about choice or truly different outcomes, you get to experience what they very strictly laid out for you. It still happens to be some fun. It isn't a good RPG, though, in many ways that have nothing to do with its retro look. A retro RPG can still be rich in choice and allow varied interactions with the environment or make exploration interesting. But this one... doesn't.

57083760.review:
I have enjoyed the game thus far. I personally feel like a private detective, and I can tell the developers put love into their game. I personally enjoyed the vacation themed armor, felt like a tip of the hat to the Ben 10 universe. Anyhow this is a review, lets get to the bones. The game's atmosphere is refreshing, however it feels simple. You can only ever do actions in combat or otherwise prompted. Sure you can walk around and run into a prompt but that's about it. I love the game's system for magic though damn if I wish it didn't front with the cybernetic augmentations. So let me get this in plain view. You can wield/equip anything you want. There are no class restrictions and you can literally build into anything though racial traits do have limits. I personally feel that magic is weak in comparison to bullets, as most weapons do 10*attribute adjustments, and magic is a base 10+(Lvl of spell) though the devs thought it was balanced due to some magic being able to ignore armor amounts. Though this innt a guide to damage output, lets continue, the story is alright, you're playing as a hired (thug/decker/mage/etc whatever you picked) that is trying to hunt down your old time thug mate who went on several jobs with you and always had your back. I am definitely hook on the plot, the whole mystery rpgs elements are unique to me, and I look forward to continuing my game. The combat is turn-based, and you have 3 slots for weapons. I chose a mage starting class but dropped my basic mage attack for a actual weapon that does damage, and I equipped spells instead. Speaking of equipment, I wish there were more options to armor. The current armor choices are all one-choice selections. Mage armor set/Decker set/Armor dealer set/etc. I wish it could have been more of a armor piece for body set. IE. Chest piece/arms/legs/etc. Although it didn't disappoint me too much to throw me off the game. That's just the equipment though lets talk more about the combat, I personally wish I had more moves, but if we take the idea of the turns as seconds it makes sense that I would only have 3 moves before my turn ends. Recap, there are weapon slots, spell slots, and also item slots. You might be wondering well what if I fill those, and I'd say get ready for a walk, because unless you are buying something your extra junk is stored in a locker at the safehouse. Wow you get a safehouse? Yes, but the game isn't open world. 56861062.review:
What these developers have been doing is taking RPG and tabletop games for video game adaptations. I thought this story was going to be a generic murder mystery, but it turned into something else that was very interesting. It seems like the dialogue choices are flavour-text and don't change the overall game outcome, but that's totally fine for a game that wants to tell a story.

Character creation is based solely around combat, and whatever classes or skills you don't take on, you can fill with teammates and mercenaries. The combat is fine for a turn-based strategy game. It can force you to diversify your team between the cyberdeck, magic, or weapon user, and the random-number game actually makes sense. I've played other TBS games that are frustrating and encourage save-scumming by having an unfair RNG, where everything hits you but you can't hit anything. This one makes sense because you can have supports buff/debuff combatants, take cover, and flank appropriately, while your enemies are trying to do the same.

A couple of pieces of advice on combat to make the game more fun: use items liberally, because you'll always find more. Focus on what you want to fight as and spend money to fill in the gaps you need. I found myself at the end of the game with way too many consumables and cash, while playing conservatively in fights which deprived me of having a lot more fun in this game.

The artwork looks great, between portraits and 3D models. It really sets the mood for a dystopia, and the NPC text really fills out the world to give an accurate picture of the huge world Shadowrun is. The writers really did a lot of work to make you feel like you're within one story in a large universe that has a history and has been lived in - without a prologue or unrealistic text-dump from an NPC.

Again, it could just be a taste thing, but I find the game as a whole to be too dull to really invest any more time into.

55150275.review:
Shadowrun Returns is the first game in the rebooted Shadowrun trilogy, along with Dragonfall and Hong Kong. Being the first game, there's definitely some hitches in the game that hold it back from being as good as the ones later on down the line. For those new to the series, Shadowrun is a cyberpunk RPG series about being a "Shadowrunner" - expendable black ops people who undertake secret missions for the highest bidder, engaging in corporate warfare and the odd bit of world-saving.

The game plays like a streamlined X-COM: turn based tactical combat using cover and abilities and the occasional rage at RNG. A very streamlined version of the tabletop system is used, and all classic shadowrun archetypes are more or less supported through the vanilla campaign. Support in user generated content ("UGC") will vary by module. The artstyle is bright and colorful with stylized caricatures of people that let you immediately identify the different metahuman races in the game at a glance. Music is mostly ambient and honestly, mostly forgettable, but fits the feel and environments you're in.

The game setup is not that of an open world, but rather linear connected levels that you cannot return to once you're finished with them. Make sure you do all of your exploring before you move on, since there's no way to "farm" money or equipment or anything. I was a little disappointed because I originally thought it was a more open world game with more sidequests - the experience in all three games is very much a linear guided experience, so know that going in.

Archetypes and skill levelling all give you abilities you'll want to use constantly. Even something as simple as a 10% aim buff, or 2 armor, is worth spamming constantly. Offensive magic is powerful as well, but I had better luck spamming things like Haste, Armor, Aim, Heal, and Barriers for my team.

There are a few gripes with the game that I have that are for the most part solved in later games:
1: Summoning spirits is just bad, IMO. You can only do it in certain parts of certain maps, and you have to give up part of your shaman's turn to do so. The more actions you let the spirit take, the more likely it is to break free and turn hostile. Alternately you can spend money on a consumable to do it anywhere, but you still have to "feed" it action points a and it can still turn hostile. It felt like a very hamfisted approach to spirit summoning. Rigger drones were much more managable.
2: The AI has an incredible bias towards attacking the main character, and the MC's death is a game over. This pretty much forces you to make a very tanky character and max Body very quickly, unless you want to have to constantly hide your character. I didn't want to do that, so I went with a physical adept and stabbed everything to death with ranged backup.
3: Money can be pretty tight until the last third of the game. If you want to be a full roided out street samurai, you'll need to save money somewhere, and you may need to do that by hiring less runners. The game is soloable by street samurai and a correctly built physical adept, it's just difficult to do so. The game is also pretty good about giving you discounts on "important" NPCs, or mandatory hires (such as Deckers), so it's easy to save money while making an effective team on the cheap. Some of the NPC runners are definitely way better than the others. Make sure you get your money's worth.
4: I found Decking to be of limited use as a main character. It does let you access some hacking and side loot, but any mission critical situation, the game gives you a mandatory decker NPC you can use that can handle the situation just fine. The matrix sections aren't difficult, and add some fun parallel combat and exploration to realspace fights.

Overall the game is a pleasant experience, and feels like a Shadowrun game. There's not a lot of "choice" to be made. Dialog options mostly exist as a way for you to inject your character's flavor into the situation. Skill checks are sometimes called for in dialogs and let you access extra information, or have extra ways of approaching situations. Especially in the second half, the game's battle maps do very well at giving you a lot of different approaches to a situation based on your team composition. I would recommend the game to anyone looking for a medium length turn based tactical game, and anyone who enjoys the Cyberpunk aesthetic. The game often goes on sale for extremely cheap,  sub 5 dollars, so keep an eye out.
